== Events == *[[Claudio Monteverdi]] marries court singer Claudia Cattaneo,<ref>Whenham, John, and Richard Wistreich, eds. ''The Cambridge Companion to Monteverdi''. Cambridge: Cambridge University Press, 2007.</ref> *[[Gregor Aichinger]] begins a two-year sojourn in Rome.
== Publications == [[Image:Luca marenzio.jpg|right|thumb|170px|[[Luca Marenzio]]]] *[[John Bennet (composer)|John Bennet]] – ''Madrigalls to Foure Voyces'' *[[John Farmer (1570-1605)|John Farmer]] – ''The First Set Of English Madrigals: To Foure Voices'' *[[Hans Leo Hassler]] – book of masses, published in [[Nuremberg]] *[[Anthony Holborne]] – ''Pavans, Galliards, Almains and other short Aeirs, both grave and light, in five parts, for Viols, Violins, or other Musicall Winde Instruments'', published in London *[[Luca Marenzio]] – Ninth book of [[Madrigal (music)|madrigals]] ''a''5
== Sacred music == *[[Philipp Nicolai]] **"[[Wachet auf, ruft uns die Stimme]]" **"[[Wie schön leuchtet der Morgenstern]]"
== Opera == *''None recorded''
== Births == *[[March 23]] – [[Thomas Selle]], composer (died 1663) *[[October 10]] – [[Étienne Moulinié]], composer (died 1676)
== Deaths == *[[January 22]] – [[Cristofano Malvezzi]], organist and composer (born 1547) *[[August 22]] – [[Luca Marenzio]], Italian composer (born c.1553) *[[October 16]] – [[Jakob Regnart]], Franco-Flemish composer (born c.1540) *[[November 8]] – [[Francisco Guerrero (composer)|Francisco Guerrero]], composer (born 1528)

{{EngvarB|date=March 2014}} {{Use dmy dates|date=March 2014}} {{Infobox film | name = Aandhi | image = Aandhi.jpg | caption = Film poster | director = [[Gulzar]] | producer = [[J. Om Prakash]]
Gulzar | writer = [[Kamleshwar]] | screenplay = Gulzar
Bhushan Banmali | starring = [[Sanjeev Kumar (actor)|Sanjeev Kumar]]
[[Suchitra Sen]] | narrator = | music = [[R.D. Burman]]
Gulzar(lyricist) | cinematography = K. Vaikunth | editing = Waman Bhonsle
Gurudutt Shirali | studio = [[Mehboob Studio]]
Natraj Studio | distributor = | released = 14 February 1975 (India) | runtime = 133 min. | country = India | language = [[Hindi]] | budget = | image size = | film_name = }} '''''Aandhi''''' ([[translation]]: Storm) is a [[Bollywood films of 1975|1975]] Indian [[political drama]] film starring [[Sanjeev Kumar]] and [[Suchitra Sen]], and directed by [[Gulzar]]. At the time it was alleged that the film was based on the life of the then-Prime Minister [[Indira Gandhi]] and her relationship with her estranged husband, but in reality, only the look was inspired by the politician [[Tarkeshwari Sinha]] and [[Indira Gandhi]]. The story is based on a chance meeting of an estranged couple after several years, when wife Aarti Devi, now a leading politician happens to stay in the hotel run by her husband during an election campaign.{{sfn|Lalit Mohan Joshi|2002|p=123}} The movie is noted for its songs composed by [[Rahul Dev Burman]], written by Gulzar and sung by [[Kishore Kumar]] and [[Lata Mangeshkar]]. [[Suchitra Sen]], the noted actress from [[Cinema of West Bengal|Bengali cinema]], who also worked in a few Hindi films, played the lead role of Aarti Devi after actress [[Vyjayanthimala]] refused the film as she had reservations about enacting the role. The movie was not allowed a full release when Mrs. Gandhi was in power. The film [[List of films banned in India|was banned]] during the [[The Emergency (India)|national emergency of 1975]] a few months after its release. The ban immediately made the film a national topic.{{sfn|Saibal Chatterjee|2003|p=247}} After her defeat in the [[Indian general election, 1977|1977 national elections]], the ruling [[Janata Party]] cleared it and had it premiered on the state-run television channel. It proved to be an important film in the career of Sen, and also her last Hindi film, as she retired from films altogether in 1978.{{sfn|Saibal Chatterjee|2003|p=247}} At the [[23rd Filmfare Awards]], she was nominated for Filmfare Best Actress Award, while Sanjeev Kumar won the [[Filmfare Award for Best Actor]]. The film itself won the [[Filmfare Critics Award for Best Movie]]. ==Plot== J.K. (played by [[Sanjeev Kumar]]) is a Hotel manager. One day he gallantly comes to the rescue of a politician's drunk daughter, Aarti ([[Suchitra Sen]]). Aarti falls in love with J.K. and both get married in a small ceremony. After few years, the married couple face many differences due to which they decide to separate. Years later, J.K. and Aarti meet again when she is an established politician. Despite the separation, both of them feel the closeness but fearing that her name might be tarnished and jeopardise her career, Aarti does not want to step forward. ==Cast== *[[Suchitra Sen]] as Aarti Devi *[[Sanjeev Kumar]] as J. K. *[[Om Shivpuri]] as Chandrasen *[[Manmohan (actor)|Manmohan]] as S. K. Agarwal *[[A. K. Hangal]] as Brinda Kaka *Kamaldeep as Chowdhary *[[C. S. Dubey]] as Gurusaran *[[Om Prakash]] as Lallu Lal, Campaign Manager *[[Rehman (actor)|Rehman]] as K. Bose ==Production== ;Development Gulzar said the film had no semblance with the personal life of then Prime Minister, [[Indira Gandhi]]. He wanted to make film about modern Indian politician, and so he modelled the character on Indira Gandhi and to some extent on noted parliamentarian from Bihar, [[Tarkeshwari Sinha]].{{cite news | url = http://www.hinduonnet.com/2001/07/20/stories/09200221.htm | title = Where is reality? | author = V.Gangadhar | work =[[The Hindu]] | date = 20 July 2001 | accessdate = 27 January 2012}} ;Script An early version of the film's story was written by veteran screenwriter [[Sachin Bhowmick]], however it did not go well with Gulzar. He had an idea of an estranged couple meeting in an hotel after years, and started developing it. Hindi writer [[Kamleshwar]] joined as the writing crew, as the film started shooting. He later went on to write a full-fledged novel, ''Kali Aandhi'' (Black Storm), which is quite different from the film. Subsequently, the film was written simultaneously along with another Gulzar film, ''[[Mausam (1975 film)|Mausam]]'' (1975), which was also written by Bhushan Banmali and Gulzar.{{cite web | title = ‘Sir’ wouldn’t lose her sleep over awards | url = http://timesofindia.indiatimes.com/entertainment/hindi/bollywood/news-interviews/Sir-wouldnt-lose-her-sleep-over-awards/articleshow/28981326.cms |date= January 18, 2014| accessdate = 2014-03-24 | publisher = The Times of India}} Along with ''[[Khushboo (1975 film)|Khushboo]]'', ''Aandhi'' also released in the same year; 1975 proving to be the most prolific for director-screenwriter Gulzar's career.{{Cite web | title = Blast From The Past: Khushboo (1975)| url = http://www.thehindu.com/features/cinema/cinema-columns/khushboo-1975/article4810769.ece | work =The Hindu | date =13 June 2013 | accessdate = 14 June 2013 }} ; Casting The lead role of Aarti Devi was offered to actress [[Vyjayanthimala]], who refused as she was fazed by physical resemblance of her character with Indira Gandhi. Later in 2011, she recounted ''Aandhi'' as one of few films she regretted not doing besides ''[[Mr and Mrs 55]]'' (1955) by [[Guru Dutt]] and ''[[Bandini (film)|Bandini]]'' (1963) by [[Bimal Roy]], "I admired Indiraji (Gandhi) so much so that I got cold feet when the role was offered to me."{{cite news | url =http://www.tribuneindia.com/2011/20111127/spectrum/book5.htm | title =From Naagin to nritya | author =Nonika Singh | work = [[The Tribune (Chandigarh)|The Tribune]] | date =27 November 2011 | accessdate = 24 March 2012}}{{cite news | url =http://www.indianexpress.com/news/down-memory-lane/874591/0 | title =Down Memory Lane | work = [[The Indian Express]] | date =12 November 2011 | accessdate = 24 March 2012}} In the early 1960s, director Gulzar had approached Suchitra Sen, with screenplay for a film to be produced by Sohanlal Kanwar, however when she suggested some changes which Gulzar didn't agree upon, the film never got made. For film ''Aandhi'' producer [[J. Om Prakash]] insisted upon Gulzar to approach Sen again and actor Sanjeev Kumar was also keen on working with Sen. This time when the new script was done, Gulzar went to meet her in Kolkata, she agreed without any script issues, resulting in a ''casting coup''. In fact, Sen now promised Gulzar to not suggest any changes, and she stuck to her promise all through the filming. For the role Aarti Devi's estranged husband [[Sanjeev Kumar]] was already cast, who had previously worked in Gulzar's ''[[Koshish]]'' (1973), again as an older man. Kumar, one of finest actors of his generation, went on to collaborate with Gulzar in numerous films, like ''Mausam'' (1975), ''[[Angoor (1982 film)|Angoor]]'' (1981) and ''[[Namkeen]]'' (1982).{{sfn|Saibal Chatterjee|2003|p=97}} ;Filming {{multiple image|caption_align=center|header_align=center | align = right | total_width = 300 | image1 = Martand Sun Temple Central shrine (6133772365).jpg | width1 = 2048 | height1 = 1536 | alt1 = | caption1 = "Tere Bina Zindagi Se" was shot at [[Martand Sun Temple]] ruins | image2 = Pari Mahal1.jpg | width2 = 640 | height2 =428 | alt2 = | caption2 ="Tum Aa Gaye Ho" was shot around [[Pari Mahal]] gardens, Srinagar. }} Like most of Gulzar's films, including ''Mausam'' and ''[[Ijaazat]]'', the narrative of Aandhi also unfolds through various [[Flashback (narrative)|flashbacks]]. {{sfn|Saibal Chatterjee|2003|p=220}}{{cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=HixlAAAAMAAJ|title=The Hundred Luminaries of Hindi Cinema|last=|first=|publisher=India Book House Publishers|year=1996|isbn=978-81-7508-007-2|location=|page=103|pages=|via=|author1=[[Dinesh Raheja]]|author2=Jitendra Kothari}} The film was almost shot together with ''Mausam'', with Sanjeev Kumar playing the lead of an old man in both the films. Though Aandhi was released first, it ran into political controversy and portions of it has to be reshot, meanwhile Mausam was completed and released.{{Cite web | title =Mausam (1975) | url =http://www.thehindu.com/features/cinema/mausam-1975/article4766190.ece | work =The Hindu | date = 30 May 2013 | accessdate = 13 June 2013 }} The songs of the film were shot at various locations in [[Jammu and Kashmir]] state, like "Tum Aa Gaye Ho" was shot around [[Pari Mahal]] gardens in [[Srinagar]], the classic "Tere Bina Zindagi Se" at the ruined 7th-8th century [[Martand Sun Temple]], near Anantnag, while "Is Mod Se Jaate Hai" was shot at [[Pahalgam]].{{cite web | title = Movie > Aandhi Locations |publisher= Filmapia | url = http://www.filmapia.com/published/movies/a/aandhi | accessdate = 2014-03-24 }}{{cite web | title = Chasing Aandhi: Kashmir sets the background|publisher=India Today| url = http://indiatoday.intoday.in/story/Chasing+Aandhi:+Kashmir+sets+the+background/1/95240.html |date=April 29, 2010| accessdate = 2014-03-24 }} Most of the songs have architectural ruins as a backdrop, depicting brokeness. Gulzar's family, wife actress [[Raakhee]] and daughter young [[Meghna Gulzar]] accompanied him on the shooting in Kashmir, however upon the return Rakhee and Gulzar separated.{{sfn|Meghna Gulzar|2004|p=121}} ==Themes and influences== In her memoir, daughter Meghna mentioned that Gulzar's wife Rakhee had once said to him, "Agar aap shayar na hote, to bade hi ordinary hote" (If you weren't a poet, you would have been very ordinary), this line was paraphrased and spoken by Aarti Devi to her husband in the film. {{sfn|Meghna Gulzar|2004|p=168}} The film looks at the life of a career-minded woman in the political arena, which is large dominated by men. Aarti inherits the legacy of her ambitious politician father, and comes in conflict with her role as dutiful wife. Soon she has to make choices to resolve the conflicts, and part ways with her husband, giving career rather duty as a daughter precedence over her personal life. When they meet again after nine years of separation, the dominating personality created under influence of her father has mellow and wisdom risen and she sees what she has missed. Yet she finds herself at a choice point once again, should she give up her political career or settle for matrimonial life. Aandhi takes on a feminist theme, also taken up in Ray's ''[[Mahanagar]]'' before, as it questions the price women often have to pay for political aspirations or career aspiration for that matter, when her unambitious hotel manager husband refuses to support.{{cite book|title=Sûrya India|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=7Vo8AAAAMAAJ|year=1989|page=71|publisher=A. Anand.}} It also satirizes the political opportunism in Indian democracy, where politicians visit the common man only every five years, at the time of elections. Through the lines of the song "Salaam kijiye aali janaab aaye hain, ye paanch saalon ka dene hisaab aaye hain. (Bow to the masters.. They have come after five years...).{{cite book|author=Bhawana Somaaya|authorlink=Bhawana Somaaya|author2=Jigna Kothari |author3=Supriya Madangarli |title=Mother Maiden Mistress|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=Dtec0Ykfo1sC&pg=PA1973-IA1|publisher=HarperCollins Publishers|isbn=978-93-5029-485-7|pages=1973}} ==Awards and nominations == At the [[23rd Filmfare Awards]] held in 1976, the film was nominated in various categories. {| class="wikitable" |- ! Award !! Category !! Recipient !! Result |- | [[Filmfare Award]] || [[Filmfare Award for Best Actor|Best Actor]]|| [[Sanjeev Kumar]] || {{Won}} |- | Filmfare Award || [[Filmfare Critics Award for Best Movie|Best Film (Critics)]] || [[Gulzar]] || {{Won}} |- | Filmfare Award || [[Filmfare Award for Best Movie|Best Film]] || || {{Nom}} |- | Filmfare Award || [[Filmfare Award for Best Director|Best Director]] || Gulzar || {{Nom}} |- | Filmfare Award || [[Filmfare Award for Best Actress|Best Actress]] || [[Suchitra Sen]] || {{Nom}} |- | Filmfare Award || [[Filmfare Award for Best Story|Best Story]] || [[Kamleshwar]] || {{Nom}} |- | Filmfare Award || [[Filmfare Award for Best Lyricist|Best Lyricist]] || Gulzar for "Tere Bina Zindagi Se Koi" || {{Nom}} |- |} ==Soundtrack== {{Infobox album | name = Aandhi: The Original Motion Picture Soundtrack | type = soundtrack | artist = [[Rahul Dev Burman]] | cover = | alt = | released = {{Start date|1975}} | recorded = | venue = | studio = | genre = | length = | label = HMV | producer = | prev_title = | prev_year = | next_title = | next_year = }} The music of this film was composed by [[Rahul Dev Burman]] with lyrics by [[Gulzar]]. Director-lyricist Gulzar first worked with Burman or Pancham as he commonly known as in ''[[Parichay (film)|Parichay]]'' (1972), giving popular songs like "Beeti Na Bitai Raina" and "Musafir Hoon Yaaro". In the following years their team gradually developed in the preceding years, eventually reaching a flourish in 1975 with two important film scores in the same year, ''Aandhi'' and ''[[Khushboo (1975 film)|Khushboo]]''.{{cite book|author=Raju Bharatan|title=A Journey Down Melody Lane|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=WnxABAAAQBAJ&pg=PT159|date=2010|publisher=Hay House, Inc|isbn=978-93-81398-05-0|pages=159}} Previously Gulzar had like the use of [[natural sign|pure notes]] (shuddha [[swara]]) in "Raina Beete Jai" from ''[[Amar Prem]]'' (1972) by Burman, a treatment which was used in the film's title music. The Lata Mangeshkar-Kishore Kumar duet "Is Mod Se Jaate Hain" extended the [[major scale]] usage with an added [[Sharp (music)|sharp]] (Teevra Madhyam) and reminiscence of Raga Yaman. Even the interludes included Indian classical instruments, like [[Bansuri|flute]] played by [[Hariprasad Chaurasia]], [[sarod]] by Zarin Daruwala (Sharma) and [[sitar]] by Jairam Acharya, aided by a violin ensemble. The tune of "Tere Bina.." another Lata Mangeshkar-Kishore Kumar duet, was originally created as [[Durga Puja]] song, "Jete Jete Potho Holo Deri" in Bengali, which Gulzar liked and wrote lyrics around the tune {{cite book|author=Anirudha Bhattacharjee Balaji Vittal|title=R. D. Burman: The Man, The Music|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=tg49WV0j0IAC&pg=PT87|date=2012|publisher=HarperCollins Publishers|isbn=978-93-5029-236-5|pages=85–87}} {| class="wikitable" |- !Song !!Singer(s)!!Time !!Notes |- |"Tere Bina Zindagi Se" |[[Kishore Kumar]] &
[[Lata Mangeshkar]] |5:55 |Picturised on [[Sanjeev Kumar]] & [[Suchitra Sen]] |- |"Tum Aa Gaye Ho Noor Aa Gaya" |[[Kishore Kumar]] &
[[Lata Mangeshkar]] |4:15 |Picturised on [[Sanjeev Kumar]] & [[Suchitra Sen]] |- |"Is Mod Se Jate Hain" |[[Kishore Kumar]] &
[[Lata Mangeshkar]] |5:00 |Picturised on [[Sanjeev Kumar]] & [[Suchitra Sen]] |- |"Salam Kijiye" |[[Mohammed Rafi]],
[[Amit Kumar]] & [[Bhupinder]] |6:55 |Ensemble cast |- |''Title Music'' Instrumental |[[R.D. Burman]] |2:35 | |} {{Listen | filename = Tere Bina Zindagi Se Koi.ogg | title = Tere Bina Zindagi Se Koi sample music | description = A 1 minute 28 seconds sample of one of the most popular songs of the film "Tere Bina Zindagi Se Koi". | format = [[Ogg]] | pos = right }} ===Reception=== The RD-Gulzar team created for the film, songs which were both acclaimed and also popular songs of the decade.{{cite book|author=Ganesh Anantharaman|title=Bollywood Melodies: A History of the Hindi Film Song|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=lmrSLuBwbKkC&pg=PA69|accessdate=13 June 2013|date=January 2008|publisher=Penguin Books India|isbn=978-0-14-306340-7|pages=12}} Songs like "Tere Bina Zindagi", "Tum Aa Gaye Ho" and "Is Mod Se Jate Hain" are considered eternal classics in Indian cinema. Songs "Tere Bina Zindagi Se" and "Is Mod Se Jate Hain" were listed 5th and 14th respectively on [[Binaca Geetmala annual list 1975]]. As per Planet Bollywood listings, "Tere Bina Zindagi Se" stands number 2 amongst top 10 Bollywood songs of the 1970s.{{cite book|author=Anna Morcom|title=Hindi Film Songs and the Cinema|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=kfVdxiSm-aYC&pg=PA253|date=2007|publisher=Ashgate Publishing|isbn=978-0-7546-5198-7|pages=253}} ==Release, ban and re-release== {{see|Emergency in India}} The film released in February 1975 amidst controversy, as rumours abound that it was based on the life of Prime Minister [[Indira Gandhi]]. Some of film's posters also hyped the similarity, with lines like, "See your Prime Minister on screen" and "the story of a great woman political leader in post-Independence India", were featured in a film magazine. Eventually, the film was given a go ahead after it was seen by two staff members and then [[Minister of Information and Broadcasting (India)| Information and Broadcasting minister]], [[I.K. Gujral]]. After the release, similarity was seen in the dressing and mannerism of lead Aarti Devi, played by Suchitra Sen and Mrs Gandhi, including the [[saree]]s and streak of white hair. During the June [[Elections in Gujarat|Legislative assembly election]] campaign in Gujarat, some opposition politicians were shown scenes of the film, depicting Aarti Devi smoking and drinking. As the film gained momentum, some ambitious exhibitors even started promoting the film with the line, "See Indira Gandhi in Aandhi", by now film was openly courting controversy, despite being only a mild satire on politicians. The film was eventually banned after 26 weeks after its release.{{cite book|author=Anirudha Bhattacharjee Balaji Vittal|title=R. D. Burman: The Man, The Music|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=tg49WV0j0IAC&pg=PT25|publisher=HarperCollins Publishers|isbn=978-93-5029-236-5|pages=25–}}{{cite book|author1=Aruna A. Vasudev|author2=Philippe Lenglet|title=Indian Cinema Superbazaar|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=8CzQAAAAMAAJ|year=1983|page=194|publisher=Vikas|isbn=978-0-7069-2226-4}} In June [[The Emergency (India)|State of Emergency]] was declared in India by Mrs. Gandhi and on 12 July despite heavy press censorship, ''[[The Statesman (India)|The Statesman]]'' managed to carry the headline on its front page, "Screening on Aandhi banned".{{cite book|author=Chitra Kanungo|title=Freedom Under Assault|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=A4KoSCutpAcC&pg=PA133|year=2001|publisher=APH Publishing|isbn=978-81-7648-226-4|page=133}} Gulzar who had then taken the film to [[Moscow International Film Festival]] got the news of the ban prior to the screening. He was also informed that the film publicity posters be taken down and the prints sent back.{{sfn|Saibal Chatterjee|2003|p=425}}{{sfn|Lalit Mohan Joshi|2002|p=44}} Subsequently, while ''Mausam'' was being premiered in December 1975, portions of Aandhi were being reshot.{{sfn|Meghna Gulzar|2004|p=78}} It included the controversial drinking scene and to establish the fact it was not a biopic, a scene with Aarti Devi looking at the framed image of Indira Gandhi tells her father that she wants to serve India like Mrs Gandhi, "Woh meri ideal thi" (She is my ideal) was inserted.{{Cite web |title =Blast From The Past:Aandhi (1975) | url =http://www.thehindu.com/features/cinema/cinema-columns/aandhi-1975/article4742988.ece | work = The Hindu | date =23 May 2013 | accessdate = 13 June 2013 }}{{sfn|Meghna Gulzar|2004|p=79}} After Indira Gandhi lost the [[Indian general election, 1977|general election of 1977]] and [[Janata Party]] came to power it was re-released and also shown on the state-run national television.{{cite web|last=Sinha|first=Sayoni|title=Ten most controversial films|url=http://in.movies.yahoo.com/blogs/24fps/controversial-films-061836779.html?page=all|publisher=[[Yahoo!]]|accessdate=13 June 2013}}{{Cite web | title = The first ladies of cinema| url = http://articles.timesofindia.indiatimes.com/2010-12-14/news-interviews/28246429_1_indira-gandhi-manisha-koirala-sonia-gandhi | publisher = The Times of India | date =14 December 2010 | accessdate = 14 June 2013 }} The film went on to become biggest hit of the Sen's Bollywood career, of which Aandhi was the last film, though she did two more Bengali films before retiring from acting in 1978. {{sfn|Saibal Chatterjee|2003|p=623}} ==Critical reception== Some critics, including [[Subhash K. Jha]] have drawn thematic parallels between Indira Gandhi and her father [[Jawaharlal Nehru]] as depicted in the film also references to their personal lives. Also the role of Sanjeev Kumar, having shades of Mrs. Gandhi's husband.{{cite book|author=M. Madhava Prasad|title=Ideology of the Hindi Film: A Historical Construction|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=6OBkAAAAMAAJ|page=140|year=1998|publisher=Oxford University Press, Incorporated|isbn=978-0-19-564218-6}}{{cite book|author1=Subhash K. Jha|author2=Amitabh Bachchan|title=The Essential Guide to Bollywood|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=8u9kAAAAMAAJ|page=1974|year=2005|publisher=Lustre Press|isbn=978-81-7436-378-7}} All through the controversy, Gulzar denied any connection with Indira Gandhi, it was only after she lost the national elections in 1977 and Janata Party came to power, did he admit, "Yes, the film was made with Indira Gandhi in mind". Sanjeev Kumar on his part said, only the [[characterisation]] of his role was based on [[Feroze Gandhi]].{{citation |title= Aandhi |page=75 |year=1977 |volume=98, Part 2 |work=The Illustrated Weekly of India }} ==References== {{Reflist|2}} ==Bibliography== * ''Kali Aandhi'' (Hindi), by [[Kamleshwar]]. Rajpal and Sons, 2003. {{ISBN|9788170285625}}. * {{cite book|author=Gulzar|title=Aandhi (Screenplay)|language=Hindi|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=ZePjqooEOQgC|date=2005|publisher=Radhakrishna Prakashan|isbn=978-81-8361-004-9}} * {{cite book|author=Gulzar|title=Aandhi: A Scenario|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=s_YKGgAACAAJ|year=2007|publisher=Srishti Publishers|isbn=978-81-88575-90-9}} * {{cite book|author=Lalit Mohan Joshi|title=Bollywood: Popular Indian cinema|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=egxlAAAAMAAJ|year= 2002|publisher=Dakini Books|ref=harv}} * {{cite book|author1=Gulzar|author2=Saibal Chatterjee|title=Encyclopaedia of Hindi Cinema|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=8y8vN9A14nkC|year=2003|publisher=Popular Prakashan|isbn=978-81-7991-066-5|ref=harv}} * {{cite book|author=Meghna Gulzar|title=Because He Is--|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=y-8V_h4h5YkC&pg=PT121|year=2004|publisher=Rupa & Company|isbn=978-81-291-0364-2|ref=harv}} ==External links== {{External media |video1= {{YouTube|VTz9CzqNg28|Full movie}} }} *{{IMDb title|id=0178186|title=Aandhi}} {{FilmfareCriticsAwardBestMovie}} {{Gulzar}} [[Category:1975 films]] [[Category:1970s Hindi-language films]] [[Category:Indian drama films]] [[Category:Indian films]] [[Category:Films scored by R. D. Burman]] [[Category:Indian political films]] [[Category:Works about the Emergency (India)]] [[Category:Censorship in India]] [[Category:Films about politicians]] [[Category:Films shot in Jammu and Kashmir]] [[Category:Films about women in India]] [[Category:Indian political drama films]] [[Category:Feminist films]] [[Category:Screenplays by Gulzar]] [[Category:Films directed by Gulzar]]

revision.comment: lower case
revision.text:
'''Agnes Gavin''' (1872–1947), was an Australian actor and screenwriter in the [[Silent film|silent film era]]. She worked in collaboration with her husband [[John Gavin (director)|John Gavin]] throughout her career. She wrote the majority of his films and was arguably the first specialist screenwriter in the history of the [[Australian film industry]].<ref>Stephen Vagg, 'A Brief History of Australian Screenwriting'. Lumina Issue 7, May 2011</ref> In newspapers she was advertised as the "well known picture dramatizer"<ref>{{cite news |url=http://nla.gov.au/nla.news-article129939083 |title=Advertising. |newspaper=[[The Referee (newspaper)|The Referee]]|location=Sydney |date=19 July 1911 |accessdate=13 November 2014 |page=16 |via=National Library of Australia}}</ref> and was praised for creating "cleverly constructed stories".<ref>{{cite news |url=http://nla.gov.au/nla.news-article129933907 |title=GENERAL GOSSIP. |newspaper=[[The Referee (newspaper)|The Referee]]|location=Sydney |date=15 November 1911 |accessdate=13 November 2014 |page=16 |via=National Library of Australia}}</ref> Many of her films are considered [[Lost film|lost]].
==Early life== She was born in Sydney as Agnes Adele Wangenheim. At the age of eighteen she married Barnett Kurtz, and became Agnes Kurtz. Barnett Kurtz had attempted to divorce Agnes in March 1897. Kurtz read a letter to the court in which Agnes said she wanted a divorce; Agnes said she did not want to divorce and wrote the letter just to annoy her husband; the divorce was not granted. In December 1897 Agnes sued for the divorce on the grounds of adultery by her husband and it was granted. Their divorce was highly publicized.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://nla.gov.au/nla.news-article138631382 |title=A SINGULAR LETTER. |newspaper=[[The Australasian]] |location=Melbourne |date=4 December 1897 |accessdate=13 November 2014 |page=24 |via=National Library of Australia}}</ref><ref>{{cite news |url=http://nla.gov.au/nla.news-article145860541 |title=Without Prejudice. |newspaper=[[Table Talk (Australian newspaper)|Table Talk]] |location=Melbourne |date=3 December 1897 |accessdate=13 November 2014 |page=3 |via=National Library of Australia}}</ref>
On October 3, 1898, Agnes married stage actor [[John Gavin (director)|John Gavin]],<ref>{{cite news |url=http://nla.gov.au/nla.news-article14221038 |title=Family Notices. |newspaper=[[The Sydney Morning Herald]] |date=5 September 1899 |accessdate=13 November 2014 |page=1 |via=National Library of Australia}}</ref> and for many years they worked together in Vaudeville and [[Bland Holt]]'s stage company.
In 1904, Agnes Gavin was accused of abusing her neighbor with violent language, as well as menacing her with a hammer and threatening to chop down her door with an ax. The court ordered her bound to the peace for six months.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://nla.gov.au/nla.news-article113291119 |title=THEATRICALS IN COURT. |newspaper=[[The Evening News (Sydney)|The Evening News]]|location=Sydney |date=25 August 1904 |accessdate=13 November 2014 |page=5 |via=National Library of Australia}}</ref>
In her first marriage she had a daughter named Isadore, who died on September 12, 1917.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://nla.gov.au/nla.news-article15736854 |title=Family Notices. |newspaper=[[The Sydney Morning Herald]] |date=12 September 1917 |accessdate=13 November 2014 |page=8 |via=National Library of Australia}}</ref> John Gavin died in 1938 and Agnes followed in 1947. The couple is survived by two daughters and several grandchildren.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://nla.gov.au/nla.news-article18016149 |title=Family Notices. |newspaper=[[The Sydney Morning Herald]] |date=10 January 1947 |accessdate=13 November 2014 |page=14 |via=National Library of Australia}}</ref>
== Career == In 1910, Gavin and her husband made their first film together, [[Thunderbolt (1910 film)|''Thunderbolt'']], produced by [[H. A. Forsyth]]. John Gavin played the main character.In their next film with Forsyth, ''[[Moonlite]]'', Gavin played an aboriginal girl named Bunda Bunda while wearing [[blackface]].
Agnes Gavin then went on to write several films for [[Stanley Crick|Crick]] and [[Herbert Finlay|Finlay]], which her husband directed.
In 1911, her husband started his own production company, the Gavin Photo-Play Studio. She wrote the films he directed, occasionally playing in them alongside her husband.
The pair were best known for making films about [[bushrangers]] such as [[Captain Thunderbolt]], [[Captain Moonlite]], [[Ben Hall (bushranger)|Ben Hall]] and [[Frank Gardiner]], and [[Convicts in Australia|convict-era]] melodramas.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://nla.gov.au/nla.news-article102803043 |title=A Well-known Biograph Actor. |newspaper=[[The Newsletter: an Australian Paper for Australian People]] |location=Sydney |date=4 February 1911 |accessdate=3 October 2013 |page=3 |via=National Library of Australia}}</ref><ref>{{cite news |url=http://nla.gov.au/nla.news-article102797743 |title=A Great Australian. |newspaper=[[The Newsletter: an Australian Paper for Australian People]] |location=Sydney |date=4 November 1911 |accessdate=13 November 2014 |page=3 |via=National Library of Australia}}</ref>
An article about the making of ''Ben Hall'' said the "dramatisation of the book" was in her "capable hands."<ref>{{cite news |url=http://nla.gov.au/nla.news-article221578093 |title=BUSHRANGING PICTURES. |newspaper=[[The Sun (Sydney)|The Sun]] |issue=161 |location=Sydney |date=4 January 1911 |accessdate=9 March 2017 |page=3|edition=CRICKET |via=National Library of Australia}}</ref>
She adapted her 1917 film ''[[The Murder of Captain Fryatt]]'' into a play: ''Captain Fryatt; Or, For King and Country''.
In 1918 she and her husband moved to Hollywood, returning briefly to Australia in 1922 and then permanently in 1925.
==Filmography== *''[[Thunderbolt (1910 film)|Thunderbolt]]'' (1910) *''[[Moonlite]]'' (1910) (also known as: Captain Moonlite) *''[[Ben Hall and his Gang]]'' (1911) *''[[Frank Gardiner, the King of the Road]]'' (1911) *''[[Keane of Kalgoorlie]]'' (1911) *''[[The Mark of the Lash]]'' (1911) *''[[The Drover's Sweetheart]]'' (1911) *''[[Assigned to his Wife]]'' ([[1911 in film|1911]]) *''[[The Assigned Servant]]'' (1911) *''[[An Interrupted Divorce]]'' ([[1916 in film|1916]]) *''[[Charlie at the Sydney Show]]'' (1916) *''[[The Martyrdom of Nurse Cavell]]'' (1916) *''[[The Murder of Captain Fryatt]]'' (1917) *''[[His Convict Bride]]'' (1918) (also known as: ''For the Term of Her Natural Life'') *''[[Trooper O'Brien]]'' (1928) (originally ''The Key of Fate''<ref>{{cite news |url=http://nla.gov.au/nla.news-article128130170 |title=THE KEY OF FATE. |newspaper=[[The Sunday Times (Sydney)|The Sunday Times]] |location=Sydney |date=8 August 1926 |accessdate=3 October 2013 |page=24 |via=National Library of Australia}}</ref>)
==Scripts== *''The White Hope'' (announced 1911) *''Outlaw Ned Kelly and His Gang'' (registered in 27 December 1917)<ref>{{cite news |url=http://nla.gov.au/nla.news-article232463246 |title=PROCEEDINGS UNDER THE COPYRIGHT ACT 1912. |newspaper=[[Commonwealth of Australia Gazette]] |issue=7 |location=Australia, Australia |date=17 January 1918 |accessdate=9 March 2017 |page=57 |via=National Library of Australia}}</ref><ref>[http://recordsearch.naa.gov.au/SearchNRetrieve/Interface/DetailsReports/ItemDetail.aspx?Barcode=202286 Copyright registration] at [[National Archives of Australia]]</ref> *''Binda's Mistress of the Girl of the Soil'' (registered in 1930)<ref>[http://recordsearch.naa.gov.au/SearchNRetrieve/Interface/DetailsReports/ItemDetail.aspx?Barcode=3492816 Copyright registration] at [[National Archives of Australia]]</ref>
==Books== *''Golden Heart, or Odds On'' (1923)<ref>[http://recordsearch.naa.gov.au/SearchNRetrieve/Interface/DetailsReports/ItemDetail.aspx?Barcode=3458477 Copyright registration] at [[National Archives of Australia]]</ref> *''Money Down Brown'' (1926)<ref>[http://recordsearch.naa.gov.au/SearchNRetrieve/Interface/DetailsReports/ItemDetail.aspx?Barcode=202330 Copyright registration] at [[National Archives of Australia]]</ref>
==Plays== *''Captain Fryatt; or, for king and country : dramatised from the scenario'' (1917)
==References== {{reflist}}
==External links== *{{IMDb name|0310514}} *[https://wfpp.cdrs.columbia.edu/pioneer/ccp-agnes-gavin/ Agnes Gavin] at Women Film Pioneers Project *[http://trove.nla.gov.au/people/1477701?q=agnes+ship&c=people Agnes Gavin] at [[NLA Trove|Trove]] *[http://www.womenaustralia.info/biogs/AWE4720b.htm Agnes Gavin] at [[Australian Woman's Register]] *[http://colsearch.nfsa.gov.au/nfsa/search/summary/summary.w3p;adv=no;group=;groupequals=;page=0;parentid=;query=Person%3A%22%2FPerson%2Fkey%2F48175-1%22;querytype=;resCount=10 Agnes Gavin]{{dead link|date=October 2016 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }} at [[National Film and Sound Archive]]
{{authority control}}

revision.comment: /* Personal life */
revision.text:
{{Use mdy dates|date=July 2013}} {{Infobox person | name = Agnieszka Holland | image = MJK32641 Agnieszka Holland (Pokot, Berlinale 2017) crop.jpg | image_size = | caption = Agnieszka Holland in 2017 | birth_date = {{Birth date and age|df=y|1948|11|28}} | birth_place = [[Warsaw]], Poland | nationality = | citizenship = | education = | alma_mater = | occupation = | years_active = | known_for = | notable_works = ''[[Europa Europa]]'' (1991), ''[[In Darkness (2011 film)|In Darkness]]'' (2011), ''[[Spoor (film)|Spoor]]'' (2017) | spouse = Laco Adamik (divorced) | children = [[Katarzyna Adamik|Kasia Adamik]] (b. 1972)<ref name="Kasia Adamik"/> | awards = }} [[File:A.Holland.jpg|thumb|260 px|Agnieszka Holland]] '''Agnieszka Holland''' (born 28 November 1948) is a [[Poles|Polish]] film and television director and screenwriter. Best known for her political contributions to [[Polish cinema]], Holland is one of Poland's most eminent filmmakers. She began her career as assistant to directors [[Krzysztof Zanussi]] and [[Andrzej Wajda]], and emigrated to France shortly before the 1981 imposition of the [[martial law in Poland]].
Holland is best known for her films ''[[Europa Europa]]'' (1991) and her 2011 drama ''[[In Darkness (2011 film)|In Darkness]]'', which was nominated for [[Academy Award for Best Foreign Language Film|Best Foreign Language Film]] at the [[84th Academy Awards]].<ref name="Nominees">{{cite web|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/entertainment-arts-16700124|title=Oscars 2012: Nominees in full|accessdate=24 November 2015}}</ref> In 2017 she received [[Alfred Bauer Prize]] (Silver Bear) for her film ''[[Spoor (film)|Spoor]]'' at the [[Berlin International Film Festival]].
==Personal life== Holland was born in [[Warsaw]], Poland in 1948. She is the daughter of journalists Irena ([[married and maiden names|née]] Rybczyńska) and Henryk Holland, who was a prominent [[Polish United Workers' Party|Communist]] activist since 1935 and a captain of [[Polish People's Army|Polish Army]].<ref>[http://www.filmreference.com/film/12/Agnieszka-Holland.html Agnieszka Holland profile], FilmReference.com; accessed 24 November 2015.</ref> Holland's mother was [[Catholic]] and her father [[Jewish]], but she was not brought up in any religious faith.<ref>{{Cite web|last=Bloom|first=Nate|title=Jewish Stars: Oscar time |publisher=[[Cleveland Jewish News]]|date=February 15, 2012|url=https://www.clevelandjewishnews.com/archives/jewish-stars-oscar-time/article_6b7fda9a-581e-11e1-aeb2-001871e3ce6c.html|accessdate=}}</ref><ref name=NPRDowell>[https://www.npr.org/2012/02/19/146806258/polands-holland-exploring-holocaust-history-again NPR: "Poland's Holland, Exploring Holocaust History Again" by Pat Dowell] February 13, 2012</ref> Her father, Henryk Holland, lost his parents in a ghetto during the Holocaust, and spent most of his adult life denying his own Jewishness. Holland's mother participated in the 1944 [[Warsaw Uprising]] as a member of the [[Polish resistance movement in World War II|Polish resistance movement]]. Holland's Catholic mother [[Rescue of Jews by Poles during the Holocaust|aided several Jews]] during the Holocaust and received the [[Righteous Among the Nations]] medal from the [[Yad Vashem]] Institute in Israel.<ref name=NPRDowell />
Holland was often ill as a child, and spent much of her time writing, drawing and directing short plays with other children.<ref name="Tibbets pp. 132-143">Tibbets, John and Agnieszka Holland. “The Interview with Agnieszka Holland: The Politics of Ambiguity”, ''Quarterly Review of Film and Video''. 25:2, pp. 132-43.</ref> When she was eleven, her parents, whose marriage had been continuously contentious, divorced and her mother soon remarried a Jewish journalist, Stanislaw Brodski.
Holland describes her relationship with her father as influential, but very distant. According to Holland, "he was very interesting, very intelligent, and in the last years of his life he gave me a lot of doors to the art an the film. But he wasn't really interested in the young children and he only noticed me when he wanted to make a kind of show".<ref name=":3">{{Cite news|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/archive/lifestyle/style/1997/10/12/agnieszka-holland-a-war-on-stupidity/abdecfb2-3bd4-4ade-9a30-33a1abc82acd/|title=AGNIESZKA HOLLAND: A WAR ON STUPIDITY|last=Kempley|first=Rita|date=1997-10-12|work=Washington Post|access-date=2018-04-18|language=en-US|issn=0190-8286}}</ref> Holland recalls beings showed off to her father's friends during late night gatherings, and then being ignored in the morning when he was no longer entertaining.<ref name=":3" /> When Holland was thirteen, her father died under police interrogation while under house arrest in Warsaw. Although official reports labeled his death a suicide, his family and others believe he was murdered by the communist police, by [[defenestration]].
Holland attended the [[Stefan Batory Gymnasium and Lyceum (Warsaw, Poland)|Stefan Batory Gymnasium and Lyceum]] in Warsaw.<!--wp:nor--> After high school, she studied at the [[Film and TV School of the Academy of Performing Arts in Prague]] (FAMU) because, as she said in an interview, she thought the Czechoslovak films of the 1960s were very interesting: "I watched first films of [[Miloš Forman]], [[Ivan Passer]], and [[Vera Chytilova]]. They seemed to be fantastically interesting to me, unlike what was being made in Poland at that time".<ref>[http://www.pk.org.pl/artykul.php?id=90 Na czeskiej fali, Agnieszka Holland - wywiad] retrieved March 9, 2013</ref> At FAMU, she also met her future husband and fellow director, Laco Adamik.
Holland witnessed the [[Prague Spring]] of 1968 while in Czechoslovakia, and was arrested for her support of the dissident movement for the government reforms and political liberalization. She describes her time in Prague as her "introduction to politics, violence, beauty, art, marriage, film and other arts...everything that happened to [her] after was based on this Czechoslovak experience".<ref name=":4">{{Cite news|url=https://filmmakermagazine.com/85231-the-only-place-to-execute-some-kind-of-power-was-the-film-set-agnieszka-holland-on-her-career/|title="The only place to execute some kind of power was the film set": Agnieszka Holland on her career {{!}} Filmmaker Magazine|last=Tong|first=Allan|work=Filmmaker Magazine|access-date=2018-04-18|language=en-US}}</ref> During her time in prison, she spent time in a cell between two inmates who had fallen in love. It became her job to pass erotic notes and messages between them. Holland herself said that "it was like phone sex and I was the cable".<ref name=":3" /> It was during her time in Prague and in prison that she realized "shed rather be an artist than an agitator".<ref name=":3" /> Holland graduated from FAMU in 1971.<ref name="Crnković 1999 pp. 2-9">Crnković, Gordana & Holland, Agnieszka. [http://www.tandfonline.com/doi/abs/10.1080/10509200601074751 “Interview with Agnieszka Holland”], ''Quarterly Review of Film and Video'', Vol. 52, No 2 (Winter, 1998-1999), pp. 2-9 (download)</ref> She returned to Poland and wrote her first screenplay. Though it was censored and stopped from being developed, it attracted the attention of [[Andrzej Wajda|Andrezej Wajda]], who became her mentor. Her daughter with Adamik, Kasia (born 28 December 1972), is also a director.<ref name="Kasia Adamik">{{cite web|url=http://www.filmpolski.pl/fp/index.php?osoba=1131970|title=Kasia Adamik|publisher=Film Polski|accessdate=16 February 2014}}</ref>
The events and confusing identities that made up her childhood resulted in Holland being known to have a signifiant struggle with identity, which manifests itself in many of her most famous films, specifically those related to Polish-Jewish interactions during the Holocaust. According to Holland, the tense relationship between Polish natives and Jewish Poles is still an ongoing issue. She says that "some Jews from Poland are still hostile to the Polish...There are things in Catholicism and Polish nationalism which are deeply anti-Semitic".<ref name=":2">{{Cite journal|last=Brunette|first=Peter |date=1986|title=Lessons from the Past: An Interview with Agnieszka Holland |jstor=41686850|journal=Cineaste |volume=15 |number=1 |pages=15–17 }}</ref> Her widely acclaimed film ''Europa, Europa'' brought her success and recognition in Hollywood, but she has always, and still faces trouble in her career and life due to her past. Holland's "mixed Polish Catholic and Jewish ancestry...places her at the hub of this century's violence".<ref name=":5">{{Cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/1993/08/08/magazine/holland-without-a-country.html|title=Holland Without a Country|last=Cohen|first=Roger|access-date=2018-04-18|language=en}}</ref> Theses conflicts and hardships have been the inspiration for films such as ''[[Europa Europa|Europa, Europa]]'' and ''[[In Darkness (2011 film)|In Darkness.]]''
==Career== [[File:Pokot w Nowej Rudzie.jpg|thumb|Discussion with Holland at the premiere of ''[[Spoor (film)|Spoor]]'' in [[Nowa Ruda]], south-western Poland]]
Holland began her career as an assistant director for Polish film directors [[Krzysztof Zanussi]] and [[Andrzej Wajda]]. Her credits include Zanussi's 1973 film, ''Iluminacja'' (''Illumination''), and Wajda's 1983 film, ''[[Danton (1983 film)|Danton]]''. She was first assistant director on Wajda's 1976 ''[[Man of Marble]]'', an experience which gave her the capability to explore political and moral issues within the confines of an oppressive regime.<ref name="Tibbets pp. 132-143"/> Though she had a large role to play in the success of this film, her name was kept off of the credits because of censorship laws.<ref name="Crnković 1999 pp. 2-9" /> In the first part of her career, Holland was unable to release any films under her own name because of the harsh censorship of Communist authorities. Wajda offered to adopt her but she refused, convinced that she could eventually release films under own name. Her first major film was ''[[Provincial Actors]]'' (''Aktorzy Prowincjonalni''), a 1978 chronicle of tense backstage relations within a small-town theater company which was an allegory of Poland's contemporary political situation. It won the International Critics Prize at the 1980 [[Cannes Film Festival]].
Holland directed two more major films in Poland, ''[[Fever (1981 film)|Fever]]'' (Gorączka, 1980, entered in the [[31st Berlin International Film Festival]]<ref name="berlinale">{{cite web |url=http://www.berlinale.de/en/archiv/jahresarchive/1981/03_preistr_ger_1981/03_Preistraeger_1981.html |title=Berlinale 1981: Prize Winners |accessdate=August 29, 2010 |work=berlinale.de}}</ref>) and ''[[A Lonely Woman]]'' (''Kobieta samotna'') in 1981, before emigrating to France shortly before the December 1981 imposition of [[martial law in Poland]]. She was told that she could not return to Poland, and was unable to see or even have any contact with her daughter for over eight months.<ref name="Crnković 1999 pp. 2-9"/> During this time, though safe, Holland was unable to create any successful films on her own.
Knowing she could not return to communist Poland, Holland wrote scripts for fellow Polish filmmakers in exile: Wajda's ''Danton'', ''[[A Love in Germany]]'' (1983), ''[[The Possessed (1988 film)|The Possessed]]'' (1988) and ''[[Korczak (film)|Korczak]]'' (1990). She also developed her own projects with Western European production companies, directing ''[[Angry Harvest]]'' (1985), ''[[To Kill a Priest]]'' (1988) and ''[[Olivier, Olivier]]'' (1992).<ref name="Crnković 1999 pp. 2-9"/> Holland received an [[Academy Awards|Academy Award]] nomination for Best Foreign Language Film for ''Angry Harvest'', a German production about a Jewish woman on the run during World War II.<ref name="Oscars1986">{{Cite web|url=http://www.oscars.org/oscars/ceremonies/1986 |title=The 58th Academy Awards (1986) Nominees and Winners |accessdate=November 10, 2013 |work=oscars.org}}</ref>
=== Holland's Depiction of the Holocaust === Some of Holland's most famous work has been her depictions of the Holocaust. These works have been extremely controversial because of Holland's commitment to realism, and the acceptance of all types of individuals as both victims and as flawed human beings deserving of guilt. According to an article written about Holland, her films about the Holocaust "cling to the world as she sees it. A world in which wisdom, if it exists at all, lies in accepting the violence and human frailty in everyone, without exception, including Jewish people".<ref name=":2" /> This is most poignant in Holland's 2011 film ''In Darkness,'' in which Jewish and Polish Catholic characters are juxtaposted as having some of the same reprehensible qualities as well as redeemable ones.
Holland's best-known film may be ''[[Europa Europa]]'' (1991), which was based on the life of [[Solomon Perel]] (a Jewish teenager who fled Germany for Poland after ''[[Kristallnacht]]'' in 1938). At the outbreak of World War II and the [[German invasion of Poland]], Perel fled to the [[Soviet Union|Soviet]]-occupied section of the country. Captured during the German invasion of the USSR in 1941, Solomon convinced a German officer that he was German and found himself enrolled in the Hitler Youth. The film received a lukewarm reception in Germany, and the German Oscar selection committee did not submit it for the 1991 Best Foreign Language Film Oscar. However, it attracted the attention of Michael Barker (who handled [[Orion Classics]]’ sales at the time). ''Europa, Europa'' was released in the United States, winning the 1991 [[Golden Globe Award for Best Foreign Language Film]] and an Oscar nomination for best adapted screenplay.<ref name="Tibbets pp. 132-143" />
Almost twenty years later, Holland released ''[[In Darkness (2011 film)|In Darkness]]'' (2011), a German-Canadian-Polish co production that dramatized the story of a Polish sewage worker who aided a group of Jewish refugees by hiding them in the sewers of Lwów during the time when Jewish people in the city were being sent to extermination camps. The story focuses on the relationships between Native Poles and Jewish people during the Holocaust. The characters of ''In Darkness'' are shown to us as having some strong similarities, despite the fact that the realities for Jews and Ethnic Poles, specifically those depicted specifically in the film, are extremely different. By comparing The Polish protagonist to the Jewish ones, Holland recreates the morally confusing  and physically brutal world that though very different for those who were hunted, was everywhere during the Third Reich. This juxtapostion seemed to be clear reflection of Holland's own personal experience, specifically her struggle with identity and anti-semitism.
=== Holland and Hollywood === Until her successful 1991 film ''Europa, Europa,'' Holland was barely recognized as an acclaimed filmmaker in Hollywood. The film came about because of a roller coaster ride with the future producer of the film: [[Artur Brauner]]. Holland had been treated to day at Disneyland by the American Academy when she was in the running as a nominee for a foreign Oscar for her film ''[[Angry Harvest]].'' After the difficultly she had getting ''Angry Harvest'' made, she had almost decided to give up filmmaking once and for all, but Brauner was convinced he had a perfect project for her. During her trip to Disney, Holland, "against her better judgement decided to ride a roller coaster with her producer. After they stepped off, Holland was shaking with fear as Brauner whipped a contract out of his pocket: "Sign!"".<ref name=":4" /> The success of this film got the attention of mainstream Hollywood, which is what gave Holland the opportunity to direct the film adaption of the 1911 world famous novel: ''[[The Secret Garden]].'' This was Holland's first movie made for a major studio with a broad American public in mind. It was a huge change in style for Holland, who was known at the point for her generally dark and pessimistic directorial perspective.<ref name=":5" />
=== Holland's Later Career === A friend of Polish writer and director [[Krzysztof Kieślowski]], Holland collaborated on the screenplay for his film, ''[[Three Colors: Blue]]''. Like Kieślowski, Holland frequently examines issues of [[faith]] in her work. Much of her film work has a strong political slant. Government reprisals, stifling bureaucratic machinery, sanctioned strikes and dysfunctional families are represented in her early work.<ref name="Tibbets pp. 132-143"/> In a 1988 interview Holland said that although women were important in her films, [[feminism]] was not the central theme of her work. She suggested that when she was making films in Poland under the [[Communist]] regime, there was an atmosphere of cross-gender solidarity against [[censorship]] (the main political issue). Holland said that she was interested in happenings between people, not the politics occurring outside them; in this context, “maybe you could say that all my movies are political.”<ref name="Crnković 1999 pp. 2-9"/> [[File:Agnieszka Holland gwiazda Lodz.jpg|thumb|left|250px|Star to honor Agnieszka Holland in [[Łódź]]]] Holland's later films include ''Olivier, Olivier'' (1992), ''[[The Secret Garden (1993 film)|The Secret Garden]]'' (1993), ''[[Total Eclipse (film)|Total Eclipse]]'' (1995), ''[[Washington Square (film)|Washington Square]]'' (1997), the HBO production ''[[Shot in the Heart]]'' (2001), ''[[Julie Walking Home]]'' (2001), and ''[[Copying Beethoven]]'' (2006).{{citation needed|date=November 2015}}
In a 1997 interview, when asked how her experiences as a director have influenced her films, Holland said “filmmakers of the younger generation lack life experience” and, as a result, lack many of the tools needed to breathe humanity into their characters. Compared to directors of her generation, she feels that the younger generation comes from wealthy families, goes straight to film schools and watches movies primarily on videotape. Holland suggests that this results in what she calls a “numbness” and “conventionalization” of contemporary cinema.<ref name="Crnković 1999 pp. 2-9"/>
In 2003, Holland was a member of the jury at the [[25th Moscow International Film Festival]].<ref name="Moscow2003">{{cite web|url=http://www.moscowfilmfestival.ru/miff34/eng/archives/?year=2003 |title=25th Moscow International Film Festival (2003) |accessdate=1 April 2013 |work=MIFF |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130403123906/http://moscowfilmfestival.ru/miff34/eng/archives/?year=2003 |archivedate=April 3, 2013 }}</ref> The following year she directed "[[Moral Midgetry]]", the eighth episode of the third season of the [[HBO]] drama series ''[[The Wire (TV series)|The Wire]]''.<ref name="E33">{{cite episode|title=Moral Midgetry|episodelink=Moral Midgetry (The Wire episode)|series=The Wire|serieslink=The Wire (TV series)|credits=Agnieszka Holland, David Simon (story), Richard Price (story and teleplay)|network=HBO|airdate=14 November 2004|season=3|number=08}}</ref><ref name="EG33">{{cite web|year=2004|title=Episode guide - episode 33 Moral Midgetry|publisher=HBO|accessdate=9 August 2006|url=http://www.hbo.com/thewire/episode/season3/episode08.shtml}}</ref><ref name="The Wire season 3 crew">{{Cite web|url=http://www.hbo.com/thewire/cast/crew/season_3.shtml|title=''The Wire'' season 3 crew|accessdate=14 October 2007|publisher=HBO|year=2007|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20071012034651/http://www.hbo.com/thewire/cast/crew/season_3.shtml|archivedate=October 12, 2007 |deadurl=no}}</ref>
In 2006, Holland returned to direct the eighth episode of the fourth season ("[[Corner Boys (The Wire episode)|Corner Boys]]").<ref name="E45">{{cite episode|title=Corner Boys|episodelink=Corner Boys (The Wire episode)|series=The Wire|serieslink=The Wire (TV series)|credits=Agnieszka Holland, Ed Burns (story), Richard Price (story and teleplay)|network=HBO {{!}} station |airdate=5 November 2004|season=4|number=08}}</ref><ref name="EG45">{{cite web|year=2006|title=Episode guide - episode 45 Corner Boys|publisher=HBO|accessdate=9 November 2006|url=http://www.hbo.com/thewire/episode/season4/episode08.shtml}}</ref><ref name="The Wire season 4 crew">{{Cite web|url=http://www.hbo.com/thewire/cast/crew/season_4.shtml|title=''The Wire'' season 4 crew|accessdate=14 October 2007|publisher=HBO|year=2007|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20071012034656/http://www.hbo.com/thewire/cast/crew/season_4.shtml|archivedate=October 12, 2007 |deadurl=no}}</ref> Both were written by novelist [[Richard Price (writer)|Richard Price]]. [[Show runner]] [[David Simon (writer)|David Simon]] said that Holland was "wonderful behind the camera" and staged the fight between [[Avon Barksdale]] and [[Stringer Bell]] in "Moral Midgetry" well.<ref name="Jim King David Simon interview 3">{{Cite web|url=http://members.aol.com/TheWireHBO/exclusive4-5.html|title=3rd Exclusive David Simon interview|accessdate=November 5, 2007|publisher=The Wire at AOL|year=2003|author=Jim King}}, p. 5</ref>
In 2007 Holland, her sister [[Magdalena Łazarkiewicz]] and her daughter Katarzyna Adamik directed the Polish political drama series ''[[Ekipa (TV Series)|Ekipa]]'', and in 2008 Holland became the first president of the [[Polish Film Academy]]. On 5 February 2009, the ''[[Krakow Post]]'' reported that Holland would direct a [[biopic]] about [[Krystyna Skarbek]] entitled ''Christine: War My Love''.<ref>[http://www.krakowpost.com/articles/2009/02/05/1233.html ''Krakow Post'' re film to be made of Krystyna Skarbek/Christine Granville's life by A. Holland] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090401034149/http://www.krakowpost.com/articles/2009/02/05/1233.html |date=April 1, 2009 }}, krakowpost.com; accessed 24 November 2015.</ref>
Her 2011 film, ''[[In Darkness (2011 film)|In Darkness]]'', was selected as the Polish entry for the [[Academy Award for Best Foreign Language Film|Best Foreign Language Film]] at the [[84th Academy Awards]].<ref name="84th">{{cite web|url=http://blogs.indiewire.com/thompsononhollywood/2011/07/15/agnieszka_hollands_in_darkness_selected_as_polish_candidate_for_oscars |title=Poland to Submit Agnieszka Holland's In Darkness for Oscars |accessdate=22 August 2011 |work=indiewire.com |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110818053242/http://blogs.indiewire.com/thompsononhollywood/2011/07/15/agnieszka_hollands_in_darkness_selected_as_polish_candidate_for_oscars/ |archivedate=August 18, 2011 }}</ref> In January 2012, the film was one of the five nominees.<ref name=Nominees/>
Holland accepted an offer to film a three-part drama for HBO about [[Jan Palach]], who immolated himself in January 1969 to protest "normalization" after the [[Warsaw Pact invasion of Czechoslovakia]] in August 1968. The resulting miniseries, ''[[Burning Bush (mini-series)|Burning Bush]]'', has been shown in Poland and Germany<ref>{{cite web|title=Beta Film Acquires Agnieszka Holland’s Burning Bush |url=http://www.filmneweurope.com/news/region/105353-beta-film-acquires-agnieszka-hollands-burning-bush/menu-id-384 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130424014506/http://www.filmneweurope.com/news/region/105353-beta-film-acquires-agnieszka-hollands-burning-bush/menu-id-384 |archivedate=April 24, 2013 }}</ref> and selected for a Special Presentation screening at the [[2013 Toronto International Film Festival]].<ref name="TIFF">{{cite web|url=http://tiff.net/filmsandschedules/festival/2013/burningbush |title=Burning Bush |accessdate=7 August 2013 |work=TIFF |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130830000309/http://tiff.net/filmsandschedules/festival/2013/burningbush |archivedate=August 30, 2013 |df=mdy }}</ref> She also won the [[Czech Lion Award]] in the Best Director category for this TV series.<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.filmovaakademie.cz/en/2013/drz-itele-ceny-cfta |title=CFTA Award Winners |access-date=2018-04-02}}</ref>
On 1 December 2013, the film screened at the National Gallery of Art in Washington, DC, where Holland was invited to deliver the Rajiv Vaidya Memorial Lecture: Viewing History through the Filmmaker's Lens.<ref name=":0">{{Cite web|url=http://www.nga.gov/content/ngaweb/audio-video/audio/agnieszka-holland.html|title=Rajiv Vaidya Memorial Lecture 2013: Viewing History Through the Filmmaker’s Lens|date=1 December 2013|accessdate=28 August 2015|website=nga.gov|publisher=National Gallery of Art|last=Holland|first=Agnieszka|type=Streaming audio recording}}</ref><ref name=":1">{{Cite web|url=http://www.nga.gov/content/dam/ngaweb/audio-video/pdf/agnieszka-holland.pdf|title=Transcript - "Viewing History through the Filmmaker's Lens"|date=1 December 2013|accessdate=28 August 2015|website=nga.gov|publisher=National Gallery of Art|last=Holland|first=Agnieszka}}</ref> It was also shown at the [http://filmadelphia.festivalgenius.com/2013/films/burningbush_agnieszkaholland_filmadelphia2013 2013 Philadelphia Film Festival.] Holland was a guest speaker at [[Brooklyn College]].
In December 2013, Holland was announced as director of NBC's next miniseries ''[[Rosemary's Baby (miniseries)|Rosemary's Baby]]'', a two-part version of the best selling novel by [[Ira Levin]] with [[Zoe Saldana]].<ref name="Culture.pl">{{cite web|url=http://culture.pl/en/article/agnieszka-holland-directs-nbc-miniseries-rosemarys-baby|title=Agnieszka Holland Directs NBC Miniseries: Rosemary's Baby|accessdate=12 December 2013|publisher=Culture.pl}}</ref>
Agnieszka Holland took over the chairmanship of the European Film Academy board in January 2014.<ref name="EFA">{{cite web|url=http://www.europeanfilmacademy.org/News-detail.155.0.html?&tx_ttnews%5Btt_news%5D=190&cHash=15194a74d380445d03227e1f0ffa557b|title=New EFA Board|accessdate=12 December 2013|publisher=EFA}}</ref>
In March 2016, it was announced that Holland is set to direct an adaptation of Peter Swanson's best-selling novel ''The Kind Worth Killing'', a psychological thriller about a ruthless female killer.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://deadline.com/2016/03/agnieszka-holland-directing-the-kind-worth-killing-1201719890/ |title=Agnieszka Holland Set To Helm ‘The Kind Worth Killing’ |author=Mike Fleming Jr. |date=16 March 2016 |website=[[Deadline Hollywood]] |publisher=[[Penske Media Corporation]] |accessdate=18 March 2016}}</ref> [[File:MJK32655 Agnieszka Mandat, Agnieszka Holland and Wiktor Zborowski (Pokot, Berlinale 2017).jpg|thumb|Holland presenting the movie ''Spoor'' at the [[Berlinale 2017]]]] In February 2017, Agnieszka Holland received The Silver Bear [[Alfred Bauer Prize]] for ''[[Spoor (film)|Spoor]]''.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://variety.com/2017/film/news/berlinale-berlin-film-festival-2017-winners-full-list-1201992021/|title=Berlin Film Festival: ‘On Body and Soul’ Wins Golden Bear for Best Film|last=Meza|first=Ed|date=2017-02-18|newspaper=Variety|access-date=2017-02-18|language=en-US}}</ref> The award is given to the films that are perceived to open new perspectives in the art of film.
==Filmography== * ''Jesus Christ's Sin'' (''Grzech Boga'', 1970) * ''Evening at Abdon's'' (''Wieczór u Abdona'', 1975) * ''Pictures from Life: A Girl and Aquarius'' (''Obrazki z życia: dziewczyna i "Akwarius"'', 1975) * ''Sunday Children'' (''Niedzielne dzieci'', 1977) * ''Screen tests'' (''Zdjęcia próbne'', 1976) * ''Something for something'' (''Coś za coś'', TV movie, 1977) * ''[[Provincial Actors]]'' (''Aktorzy prowincjonalni'', 1978, International Critics Prize at [[Cannes Film Festival]]) * ''[[Fever (1981 film)|Fever]]'' (''Gorączka'', 1980) * ''[[A Lonely Woman]]'' (''Kobieta samotna'', 1981) * ''Postcards from Paris'' (TV film, 1982) * ''[[Interrogation (1982 film)|Interrogation]]'' (1982) * ''Culture'' (documentary, 1985) * ''[[Angry Harvest]]'' (''Bittere Ernte'', 1985, Germany, Academy Award nominee for [[Academy Award for Best Foreign Language Film|the best foreign language film]]) * ''[[To Kill a Priest]]'' (1988) * ''[[Europa Europa|Europa, Europa]]'' (1990, Academy Award nominee for [[Academy Award for Writing Adapted Screenplay|the best screenplay]]) * ''[[Olivier, Olivier]]'' (1992) * ''[[The Secret Garden (1993 film)|The Secret Garden]]'' (1993) * ''Red Wind'' (TV movie, 1994) * ''[[Total Eclipse (film)|Total Eclipse]]'' (1995) * ''[[Washington Square (film)|Washington Square]]'' (1997) * ''[[The Third Miracle]]'' (1999) * ''[[Shot in the Heart]]'' (2001) * ''[[Golden Dreams]]'' (documentary, 2001) * ''[[Julie Walking Home]]'' (2002) * ''[[Copying Beethoven]]'' (2005) * ''[[The Wire (TV series)|The Wire]]'' ** Episode 3.08 "[[Moral Midgetry]]" (2004)<ref name = "E33"/><ref name = "EG33"/> ** Episode 4.08 "[[Corner Boys (The Wire episode)|Corner Boys]]" (2006)<ref name = "E45"/><ref name = "EG45"/> ** Episode 5.05 "[[React Quotes]]" (2008)<ref name = "E55">{{cite episode | title = React Quotes | episodelink = React Quotes | series = The Wire | serieslink = The Wire (TV series) | credits = Agnieszka Holland, David Mills (story and teleplay), David Simon (story) | network = HBO | station = | city = | airdate = February 3, 2008 | season = 5 | number = 5}}</ref><ref name="EG55">{{Cite web|url=http://www.hbo.com/thewire/episode/season5/episode55.shtml|title=''The Wire'' episode guide - episode 55 React Quotes|accessdate=February 5, 2008|publisher=HBO|year=2008| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20080205113753/http://www.hbo.com/thewire/episode/season5/episode55.shtml| archivedate= February 5, 2008 <!--DASHBot-->| deadurl= no}}</ref> * ''[[A Girl Like Me: The Gwen Araujo Story]]'' (2006) * ''[[Ekipa (TV Series)|Ekipa]]'' (2007) * ''[[Janosik. Prawdziwa historia]]'' (2009) * ''[[The Killing (U.S. TV series)|The Killing]]'' ** Episode 1.06 "What You Have Left" (2011) ** Episode 1.09 "Undertow" (2011) ** Episode 2.01 "Reflections" (2012) * ''[[Treme (TV series)|Treme]]'' ** Episode 1.01 "Do You Know What It Means" (2010) ** Episode 1.10 "I'll Fly Away" (2010) ** Episode 2.10 "That's What Lovers Do" (2011) ** Episode 4.05 "...To Miss New Orleans" (2013) * ''[[In Darkness (2011 film)|In Darkness]]'' (2011) (nominee for [[Academy Award for Best Foreign Language Film|Best Foreign Language Film]] award at the [[84th Academy Awards]] as Polish entry) * ''[[Burning Bush (mini-series)|Burning Bush]]'' (2013) (a three-part mini-series created for HBO)<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.culture.pl/web/english/events-calendar-full-page/-/eo_event_asset_publisher/L6vx/content/agnieszka-holland-burning-bush |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2013-02-01 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130317182335/http://www.culture.pl/web/english/events-calendar-full-page/-/eo_event_asset_publisher/L6vx/content/agnieszka-holland-burning-bush |archivedate=March 17, 2013 |df=mdy }}</ref> * ''[[Rosemary's Baby (miniseries)|Rosemary's Baby]]'' (2014) * ''[[House of Cards (U.S. TV series)|House of Cards]]'' ** Episode 3.10 "Chapter 36" (2015) ** Episode 3.11 "Chapter 37" (2015) ** Episode 5.10 "Chapter 62" (2017) * ''[[Spoor (film)|Spoor]]'' (2017) * ''[[The First (TV series)|The First]]'' ** Episode 1.01 "Seperation" (2018) ** Episode 1.02 "What's Needed" (2018)
== Other work == Agnieszka Holland translated from Czech to Polish the novel ''[[The Unbearable Lightness of Being]]''. She volunteered for this task after meeting the author, [[Milan Kundera]], in 1982, and reading the manuscript; both were living in [[Paris]] at that time. Holland found the events of the book relatable not only to her personal experience of the [[Warsaw Pact invasion of Czechoslovakia]] but also to the [[Gdańsk Agreement#Strikes of 1980|strikes of 1980]] in Poland, and therefore wanted to introduce the book to the Polish audience. The translation was originally published by the London-based publisher ''Aneks'' and has since been widely reprinted.<ref>{{cite web |title=Agnieszka Holland: Mój Kundera |url=https://www.newsweek.pl/milan-kundera-we-wspomnieniach-agnieszki-holland/b7r3tes |website=Newsweek.pl |date=1 March 2018 |accessdate=23 October 2018 |language=pl-PL}}</ref><ref>[https://books.google.co.uk/books/about/Niezno%C5%9Bna_lekko%C5%9B%C4%87_bytu.html?id=rQRKPgAACAAJ&redir_esc=y ''Nieznośna lekkość bytu'' on Google Books (modern edition)]</ref><ref>[https://books.google.co.uk/books?id=cDGci0XxNIcC&q=Niezno%C5%9Bna+lekko%C5%9B%C4%87+bytu+aneks&dq=Niezno%C5%9Bna+lekko%C5%9B%C4%87+bytu+aneks&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwjVypXbw53eAhVMYsAKHTIQDqkQ6AEILDAA ''Nieznośna lekkość bytu'' on Google Books (original ''Aneks'' publication)]</ref>
==Further reading== * {{cite book| last=Quart |first=Barbara Koenig |year=1988 |title=Women Directors: The Emergence of a New Cinema |location=[[New York City|New York]] |publisher=Praeger |isbn=0-275-93477-2}} * Agnieszka Niezgoda (conversations), Jacek Laskus (photographs). ''Hollywood PL. Beyond The Dream: Personal Roads to The Silver Screen.'' (Warsaw, Poland, 2013) Wydawnictwo Hollywood PL. {{ISBN|978-83-932192-1-6}} * Agnieszka Holland, "Viewing History through the Filmmaker's Lens," lecture delivered December 1, 2013, at the National Gallery of Art, Washington DC.<ref name=":1" /><ref name=":0" />

revision.comment: links, reference, ExtLin; added info about silver sulphamate
revision.text:
'''Argyrotype''' is an [[iron-based silver printing process]] that produces brown images on plain paper. It is an [[alternative process]] derived from the [[argentotype]], [[kallitype]], and [[Van Dyke Brown|Van Dyke processes]] of the 19th century, but has greater simplicity, improved image stability, and longer sensitizer shelf-life.<ref>Mike Ware</ref> It was developed by [[Mike Ware (photographer)|Mike Ware]].<ref name="silverprint">{{cite web|author=SuperUser|title=Argyrotype|url=http://www.silverprint.co.uk/argyrotype/|website=Silverprint|accessdate=22 October 2014}}</ref>
While this process may not have the permanence of other processes such as [[Platinum printing|platinum]] or [[palladium printing]], it is much less expensive and more user friendly. The core resource used is [[silver sulphamate]] (NH<sub>2</sub>SO<sub>3</sub>Ag) which can be prepared on site from [[sulphamic acid]].<ref name="silverprint" /> The sensitizer used is very slow, so printing must be by contact with a [[large format]] negative, using an [[ultraviolet]] lamp or sunlight.
As with most alternative processes there is room for manipulating the process to achieve different effects, and since the image is produced on plain paper many drawing or print making processes can be combined with the original image.
==References== {{Reflist}}
==External links== *[http://www.mikeware.co.uk/mikeware/Argyrotype_Process.html The Argyrotype Process by Mike Ware] *[http://www.alternativephotography.com/wp/processes/kallitypes/overview-vandyke-kallitype-argyrotype Formula overview for Vandyke, Kallitype and Argyrotype by Wynn White]
[[Category:Printmaking]]
