revision.text:
{{Use Indian English|date=May 2017}} {{Use dmy dates|date=December 2016}} {{Infobox artist | name = MF Husain | image = MFHussain2.jpg | caption = MF Husain at [[Museum of Islamic Art, Doha]] | birth_name = Maqbool Fida Husain | birth_date = {{Birth date|df=yes|1915|09|17}} | birth_place = [[Pandharpur]], [[Bombay Presidency]], [[British India]] | death_date = {{Death date and age|df=yes|2011|6|9|1915|11|29}} | death_place = [[London]], [[England]], [[United Kingdom|UK]] | nationality = Qatari | field = Painting, drawing, writing, filmmaking | training = [[Sir J. J. School of Art]] | movement = [[Bombay Progressive Artists' Group]] | works = ''[[Meenaxi: A Tale of Three Cities]]''
''Through the Eyes of a Painter'' | patrons = | awards = [[Padma Shri]] (1966)
[[Padma Bhushan]] (1973)
[[Padma Vibhushan]] (1991) }} '''Maqbool Fida Husain''' (17 September 1915 – 9 June 2011)http://www.culturalindia.net/indian-art/painters/m-f-hussain.html, also , India's Most Famous Painter, Dies at 95|work=[[The New York Times]]|date=9 June 2011|author=[[William Grimes (journalist)|William Grimes]]}} was a modern [[Indian people|Indian]] painter of international acclaim, and a founding member of [[Bombay Progressive Artists' Group]]. Husain is associated with Indian [[modernism]] in the 1940s. His early association with the Bombay Progressive Artists' Group used modern technique, and was inspired by the "new" India after [[Partition of India|The Partition]] of 1947. His narrative paintings, executed in a modified [[Cubist]] style, can be caustic and funny as well as serious and sombre. His themes—sometimes treated in series—include topics as diverse as [[Mohandas K. Gandhi]], [[Mother Teresa]], the [[Ramayana]], the [[Mahabharata]], the [[British raj]], and motifs of Indian urban and rural life. Early in his painting career, and until his death, he enjoyed depicting the lively and free spirit of horses in many of his works.Husain is the most celebrated and internationally recognized Indian artist of the 20th century. Husain is primarily known for his paintings, but is also known for his drawings and his work as a printmaker, photographer, and filmmaker. Some of his later works stirred controversy, as they depicted traditional deities of India in non-traditional ways including nude portrayals of the deities. He also directed a few movies. In 1967, he received the [[Discontinued and Intermittent National Film Awards|National Film Award for Best Experimental Film]] for ''Through the Eyes of a Painter''.{{cite web|url=http://dff.nic.in/2011/15th_nff_1967.pdf|title=15th National Film Awards|publisher=[[International Film Festival of India]]|accessdate=21 September 2011|format=PDF}} In 2004, he directed ''[[Meenaxi: A Tale of Three Cities]]'', a film he worked on with his artist son [[Owais Husain]], which was screened in the Marché du Film section of the [[2004 Cannes Film Festival]].{{cite web|url=http://www.outlookindia.com/news/article/Meenaxi-Tale-of-3-cities-screened-at-Cannes/223181|title=Meenaxi: Tale of 3 cities screened at Cannes|publisher=}} ==Biography== Husain was born on 17 September 1915 in [[Pandharpur]] to a [[Sulaymani]] Bohra family who trace their roots back to [[Gujarat]] within the last 200 years, and then originally to Yemen.{{cite web|url=http://caravanmagazine.in/essay/understanding-husain|title=Understanding Husain|date=3 May 2012|publisher=|accessdate=24 May 2017}} He picked up taste in art through studying calligraphy while he stayed at a Madraasa in [[Baroda]]. Husain attended the [[Sir Jamsetjee Jeejebhoy School of Art]] in Mumbai.{{cite news|last1=Kumar |first1=Anu |title=JJ Institute: 150 years of lettering the poor |url=http://www.indianexpress.com/res/web/pIe/ie/daily/19990109/00950535.html |work=Indian Express |date=9 January 1999 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090526071758/http://www.indianexpress.com/res/web/pIe/ie/daily/19990109/00950535.html |archivedate=26 May 2009 |deadurl=yes |df= }} Early in his career Husain painted cinema posters in Mumbai. To earn extra money, he worked for a toy company designing and building toys. He often travelled to Gujarat to paint landscapes when he could afford to.{{cite web|url=http://www.webindia123.com/personal/paint/husain.htm|title=MF Husain|accessdate=29 July 2015|publisher=Web India}}{{dead link|date=September 2017 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }} Husain developed his painting skills in the 1930s, painting billboards for the growing Bollywood film industry.{{Cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2017/07/05/arts/design/m-f-husains-modern-india-at-the-art-institute-of-chicago.html|title=M. F. Husain’s Modern India at the Art Institute of Chicago|last=Mcdermon|first=Daniel|date=2017-07-05|work=The New York Times|access-date=2017-07-17|language=en-US|issn=0362-4331}} This was a clique of young artists who wished to break with the nationalist traditions established by the [[Bengal school of art]] and to encourage an Indian avant-garde, engaged at an international level. The artists cite "The Partition" of India and Pakistan 14 August 1947, with its resulting religious rioting and heavy loss of life as their reason for forming The Progressive Artist's Group in Bombay in December 1947. The artists saw the Partition as a "turning point" for India, and their new style of art was urged on by, and was also a turning point for, (modern) Indian Art.{{cite web|url=http://www.artnewsnviews.com/view-article.php?article=progressive-artists-group-of-bombay-an-overview&iid=29&articleid=800|title=Progressive Artists Group of Bombay: An Overview|website=www.artnewsnviews.com|accessdate=24 May 2017}} Husain's first solo exhibit was in 1952 in Zurich.{{cite web|url=http://www.contemporaryindianart.com/m_f_husain.htm|title=M.F. Husain|website=www.contemporaryindianart.com|accessdate=24 May 2017|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20170523073033/http://www.contemporaryindianart.com/m_f_husain.htm|archive-date=23 May 2017|dead-url=yes|df=dmy-all}} His first U.S.A. exhibit was at India House in New York in 1964.{{cite web|url=http://www.aestheticamagazine.com/m-f-husain-master-modern-indian-painting-va-london|title=Aesthetica Magazine - M.F. Husain: Master of Modern Indian Painting, V&A, London|publisher=|accessdate=24 May 2017}}{{cite web|url=http://www.indiaonline.in/about/Personalities/Painter/MF-HUSAIN.html|title=List of Famous Indian Personalities, Great Persons in India|website=www.indiaonline.in|accessdate=24 May 2017}} In 1966, he was awarded the prestigious Padma Shri . ===1966 – 1990=== In 1967, he made his first film,''[[Through the Eyes of a Painter]]'' It was shown at the [[Berlin International Film Festival]] and won a [[Golden Bear (award)|Golden Bear short film award]].{{cite web|url=http://www.berlinale.de/en/archiv/jahresarchive/1967/03_preistr_ger_1967/03_Preistraeger_1967.html |title= Prizes and Honours 1967 |publisher=[[Berlin International Film Festival]] |date= |accessdate=30 June 2012}}{{cite news|title=M.F. Husain 'Through The Eyes Of A Painter': A chronology|url=http://www.deccanherald.com/content/167512/mf-husain-through-eyes-painter.html|accessdate=9 January 2013|newspaper=[[Deccan Herald]]|date=9 June 2011|agency=[[Indo-Asian News Service]]}} Husain was a special invitee along with [[Pablo Picasso]] at the [[Sao Paulo Biennial]] (Brazil) in 1971. {{cite web |url=http://www.paletteartgallery.com/artistbiography.asp?artistid=4 |title=M. F. Husain: M. F. Husain paintings, art work at Palette Art Gallery, India |publisher=Paletteartgallery.com |date= |accessdate=30 June 2012 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120312032707/http://www.paletteartgallery.com/artistbiography.asp?artistid=4 |archivedate=12 March 2012 |df=dmy-all }}{{better source|date=January 2013}} He was awarded the [[Padma Bhushan]] in 1973{{cite web |url=http://mha.nic.in/sites/upload_files/mha/files/LST-PDAWD-2013.pdf |title=Padma Awards |publisher=Ministry of Home Affairs, Government of India |date=2015 |accessdate=21 July 2015 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6U68ulwpb?url=http://mha.nic.in/sites/upload_files/mha/files/LST-PDAWD-2013.pdf |archivedate=15 November 2014 |df= }} and was nominated to the [[Rajya Sabha]] in 1986.{{better source|date=January 2013}} He was awarded the [[Padma Vibhushan]] in 1991. ===1990 – 2005=== His paintings allegedly hurt the religious sentiments of [[Hindutva#Cultural nationalism|Hindu nationalist groups]], which beginning in the 1990s mounted a campaign of protest against him.{{cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2011/06/10/arts/design/maqbool-fida-husain-indias-most-famous-painter-dies-at-95.html?ref=deathsobituaries|title=Maqbool Fida Husain, also , India's Most Famous Painter, Dies at 95|work=[[The New York Times]]|date=9 June 2011|author=[[William Grimes (journalist)|William Grimes]]}} The paintings in question were created in 1970, but did not become an issue until 1996, when they were printed in ''Vichar Mimansa'', a Hindi monthly magazine, which published them in an article headlined "M.F. Husain: A Painter or Butcher". In response, eight criminal complaints were filed against him. In 2004, [[Delhi High Court]] dismissed these complaints of "promoting enmity between different groups ... by painting Hindu goddesses – Durga and Sarswati, that was later compromised by Hindu fundamentalist groups."{{cite news|title=Delhi HC dismisses complaints against M.F. Husain|url=http://www.hinduonnet.com/2004/04/09/stories/2004040904231400.htm|newspaper=[[The Hindu]]|date=8 April 2004}}[http://www.hindujagruti.org/activities/campaigns/national/mfhussain-campaign/hussain_verdjkhjkhjh]{{dead link|date=May 2017 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }} In 1998 Husain's house was attacked by Hindu fundamentalist groups like [[Bajrang Dal]] and art works were vandalised. The leadership of another fundamentalist political party [[Shiv Sena]] endorsed the attack. Twenty-six Bajrang Dal activists were arrested by the police.{{cite news|last=Padmanabhan|first=R.|title=Assault on art|url=http://frontlineonnet.com/fl1510/15100210.htm|newspaper=[[Frontline (magazine)|Frontline]]|date=9–22 May 1998|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20060714034825/http://www.frontlineonnet.com/fl1510/15100210.htm|archivedate=14 July 2006|df=dmy-all}} Protests against Husain also led to the closure of an exhibition in England. He has also produced & directed several movies, including ''[[Gaja Gamini]]'' (2000) (with his [[Artistic inspiration|muse]] [[Madhuri Dixit]] who was the subject of a series of his paintings which he signed ''Fida''). The film was intended as a tribute to Ms. Dixit herself.{{cite web|title=youtube.com|work=The work of the muse|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=5aOqSTkZw7I|accessdate=12 December 2006}}{{better source|date=January 2013}} In this film she can be seen portraying various forms and manifestations of womanhood including the muse of [[Kalidasa]], the [[Mona Lisa]], a rebel, and musical euphoria. He also appeared in a scene in film ''[[Mohabbat (1997 film)|Mohabbat]]'', which had Madhuri Dixit in lead role. In the film, the paintings that were supposedly done by Madhuri were actually Husain's.{{cite news|url=http://www.deccanherald.com/content/168469/reema-nath-made-husain-act.html |title=Reema Nath made Husain act in 'Mohabbat' |newspaper=[[Deccan Herald]] |date=13 June 2011|agency=[[Indo-Asian News Service]]}} He went on to make ''[[Meenaxi: A Tale of Three Cities]]'' (with [[Tabu (actress)|Tabu]]). The film was pulled out of cinemas a day after some Muslim organisations raised objections to one of the songs in it.{{cite news|last=Kumar|first=Shiv|title=Husain pulls Meenaxi out of theatres|url=http://www.tribuneindia.com/2004/20040417/nation.htm#8|newspaper=[[The Tribune (Chandigarh)|The Tribune]]|date=16 April 2004}} The All-India Ulema Council complained that the [[Qawwali]] song ''[[Meenaxi (Soundtrack)|Noor-un-Ala-Noor]]'' was blasphemous. It argued that the song contained words directly taken from the Quran. The council was supported by Muslim organisations like the Milli Council, All-India Muslim Council, Raza Academy, Jamiat-ul-Ulema-e-Hind and Jamat-e-Islami. Husain's son stated that the words were a phrase referring to divine beauty that were being sung by the central character played by [[Tabu (actress)|Tabu]]. He said there was no intention to offend. Following the wave of protests the enraged artist withdrew his movie from cinemas. The film was well received by the critics, however, and went on to win various awards. ===2006 - 2011=== In February 2006, Husain was charged with "hurting sentiments of people" because of his nude portraits of [[Hindu deities|Hindu gods and goddesses]].{{cite news|title=M F Husain booked for his paintings of nude gods|url=http://ia.rediff.com/news/2006/feb/07nude.htm|publisher=[[Rediff]]|date=7 February 2006|agency=[[Press Trust of India]]}} In addition, in 6 February 2006 issue, ''[[India Today]]'', a national English weekly published an advertisement titled "Art For Mission Kashmir". This advertisement contains a painting of {Bharatmata} (Mother India) as a nude woman posed across a map of India with the names of Indian States on various parts of her body. The exhibition was organised by [[Nafisa Ali]] of Action India (NGO) and Apparao Art Gallery. Organizations like [[Vishva Hindu Parishad]] (VHP) have protested persistently against Husain displaying the painting on the websites and even in exhibitions in north Europe. As a result, Husain apologized and promised to withdraw the painting from an auction, which was later sold for Rs 80 lakh in the auction.{{cite news|title=MF Hussain apologises for obscene paintings|url=http://articles.timesofindia.indiatimes.com/2006-02-07/india/27814790_1_hjs-m-f-hussain-noted-painter|newspaper=[[The Times of India]]|date=7 February 2006|agency=[[Press Trust of India]]}}{{cite news|title=HJS lodges FIR against Nafisa Ali for selling Hussain's art|url=http://www.outlookindia.com/pti_news.asp?id=354472|newspaper=[[Outlook India]]|date=10 February 2006|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20071204065111/http://www.outlookindia.com/pti_news.asp?id=354472|archivedate=4 December 2007|df=dmy-all}} The painting later appeared on Husain's official website. Husain became the best-paid painter in India, his highest-selling piece fetching $1.6 million at a 2008 [[Christie's]] auction.{{cite news|last=Mittra|first=Anwesha|title=MF Husain: A life well lived|url=http://articles.timesofindia.indiatimes.com/2011-06-09/people/29637678_1_gaja-gamini-mf-husain-painter|newspaper=[[The Times of India]]|date=9 June 2011}}{{cite news|last=Jana|first=Reena|title=The Late M.F. Husain, Already an Icon of Indian Art, Becomes a Market Darling|url=http://www.artinfo.com/news/story/846892/the-late-mf-husain-already-an-icon-of-indian-art-becomes-a|newspaper=[[Art+Auction]]|date=11 December 2012}} Hundreds of lawsuits in connection with Husain's allegedly obscene art were outstanding as of 2007.{{cite news|title=Husain’s property: SC issues stay order|url=http://archives.dawn.com/dawnftp/72.249.57.55/dawnftp/2007/05/09/int8.htm|newspaper=[[Dawn (newspaper)|Dawn]]|date=8 May 2007|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://archive.is/20130215193355/http://archives.dawn.com/dawnftp/72.249.57.55/dawnftp/2007/05/09/int8.htm|archivedate=15 February 2013|df=dmy-all}} A warrant was issued for his arrest after he did not appear at a hearing, though this warrant was later suspended.{{cite news|title=MF Husain, a self-taught artist|url=http://articles.timesofindia.indiatimes.com/2011-06-09/india/29638271_1_hindu-gods-hindu-groups-mf-husain|newspaper=[[The Times of India]]|date=9 June 2011|agency=[[Press Trust of India]]}}{{cite news|url=http://www.taiwannews.com.tw/etn/news_content.php?id=445526 |title=India's Supreme Court suspends arrest warrant for artist M.F. Husain |agency=[[Associated Press]] |newspaper=[[Taiwan News]]|date=29 March 2009}} Husain also received death threats.{{failed verification |date=January 2016}} Husain lived in self-imposed exile from 2006 until his death. He generally lived in [[Doha]] and summered in London.{{cite news|last=Ram|first=N.|title=M.F. Husain gets Qatar nationality|url=http://www.thehindu.com/news/national/article113018.ece|newspaper=[[The Hindu]]|date=25 February 2010}} For the last years of his life Husain lived in Doha and London, staying away from India, but expressing a strong desire to return, despite fears of being killed.{{cite news|url=http://www.dnaindia.com/report.asp?NewsID=1095086|title=Police attach MF Husain's property in Mumbai|date=6 May 2007|agency=[[Press Trust of India]]|newspaper=[[Daily News and Analysis]]}} In 2008 Husain was commissioned to create 32 large-scale paintings of Indian history. He finished 8 before his death. In 2010, he was conferred Qatari nationality, and he surrendered his Indian passport.{{cite news|title=MF Husain dead at 95|url=http://indiatoday.intoday.in/story/celebrated-painter-m-f-husain-dead/1/140914.html|newspaper=[[India Today]]|date=9 June 2011}}{{cite news|title=Has India lost its Husain forever?|url=http://www.ndtv.com/article/india/has-india-lost-its-husain-forever-16825|accessdate=9 January 2013|publisher=[[NDTV]]|date=25 February 2010}} In Qatar, he principally worked on two large projects, one on the history of Arab civilization, commissioned by Qatar's first lady, [[Mozah bint Nasser Al Missned]], and one on the history of Indian civilization. The works are to be housed in a museum in [[Doha]]. At the age of 92 Husain was given the prestigious [[Raja Ravi Varma]] award by the government of [[Kerala]].{{cite news|title=MF Husain selected for Raja Ravi Varma award|url=http://www.hindustantimes.com/News-Feed/India/MF-Hussain-selected-for-Raja-Ravi-Varma-award/Article1-222279.aspx|newspaper=[[Hindustan Times]]|date=12 May 2007|agency=[[Press Trust of India]]|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120307124948/http://www.hindustantimes.com/News-Feed/India/MF-Hussain-selected-for-Raja-Ravi-Varma-award/Article1-222279.aspx|archivedate=7 March 2012|df=dmy-all}} The announcement led to controversy in Kerala and some cultural organisations campaigned against the granting of the award and petitioned the Kerala courts. Social Activist, [[Rahul Easwar]], went to Kerala High Court and it granted an interim order to stay the granting of the award until the petition had been disposed of.{{cite news|url=http://www.hindu.com/2007/09/14/stories/2007091460170400.htm |title=High Court restraint on award for M.F. Husain |newspaper=[[The Hindu]] |date=14 September 2007}} In 2010, the Jordanian [[Royal Islamic Strategic Studies Centre]] named Husain as one of the 500 most influential Muslims.{{cite web |url=http://www.rissc.jo/docs/0A-FullVersion-LowRes.pdf | title=The 500 Most Influential Muslims|publisher=The Royal Islamic Strategic Studies Centre | accessdate=3 January 2011|format=PDF}} [[File:M F Husain Grave Brookwood.jpg|thumb|right|Grave of M. F. Husain in [[Brookwood Cemetery]] in [[Surrey]], [[England]].]] M. F. Husain died, aged 95, on 9 June 2011, following a heart attack. He had been unwell for several months.{{cite news|title=India's most highly prized artist MF Husain dies aged 95|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-south-asia-13708844|publisher=[[BBC News]]|date=9 June 2011}} He died at the [[Royal Brompton Hospital]] in London, and was buried in [[Brookwood Cemetery]] on 10 June 2011.{{cite news|url=http://blogs.independent.co.uk/2011/06/09/mf-husain-dies-%E2%80%93-lauded-in-exile-by-india%E2%80%99s-artistic-fraternity/|first=John|last=Elliott|title=MF Husain dies – lauded in exile by India's artistic fraternity|newspaper=[[The Independent]]|date=9 June 2011|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120418054453/http://blogs.independent.co.uk/2011/06/09/mf-husain-dies-%E2%80%93-lauded-in-exile-by-india%E2%80%99s-artistic-fraternity/|archivedate=18 April 2012|df=dmy-all}} Other Indian artists expressed criticism. [[Satish Gujral]] publicly asked Husain whether he would dare to portray Islamic figures similarly.{{cite news|title=A brush with genius|url=http://www.hindustantimes.com/News-Feed/nm17/A-brush-with-genius/Article1-153431.aspx|newspaper=[[Hindustan Times]]|date=24 September 2006|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20121022035103/http://www.hindustantimes.com/News-Feed/nm17/A-brush-with-genius/Article1-153431.aspx|archivedate=22 October 2012|df=dmy-all}} However Gujral stated that he deeply regretted the way Husain was treated and forced into an exile because of what Gujral termed "the mob culture".{{cite news|last=Gupta |first=Shekar |title=On the record: 'Husain's exile makes me ashamed of my culture. . . the state hasn't expelled him, mob culture has' |url=http://www.indianexpress.com/story/293365-3.html |newspaper=[[Indian Express]] |date=7 April 2008 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080511140359/http://www.indianexpress.com/story/293365-3.html |archivedate=11 May 2008 }} Writing in ''[[The Pioneer (daily)|The Pioneer]]'', Chandan Mitra wrote, "As long as such a law exists in the statutes, nobody can be faulted for approaching the courts against Husain's objectionable paintings, nor can the judiciary be pilloried for ordering action against the artist for his persistent and deliberate refusal to appear before the court."{{cite news|last=Mitra |first=Chandan |title=Art for God's sake |url=http://www.dailypioneer.com/columnist1.asp?main_variable=Columnist&file_name=mitra%2Fmitra250.txt&writer=mitra |accessdate=27 September 2007 |newspaper=[[The Pioneer (newspaper)|The Pioneer]] |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070927035639/http://www.dailypioneer.com/columnist1.asp?main_variable=Columnist&file_name=mitra%2Fmitra250.txt&writer=mitra |archivedate=27 September 2007 }} In response to the controversy, Husain's admirers petitioned the government to grant Husain the [[Bharat Ratna]], India's highest award. According to [[Shashi Tharoor]], who supported the petition, it praised Husain because his "life and work are beginning to serve as an allegory for the changing modalities of the secular in modern India – and the challenges that the narrative of the nation holds for many of us. This is the opportune and crucial time to honour him for his dedication and courage to the cultural renaissance of his beloved country."{{cite news|last=Tharoor|first=Shashi|title=Our stories|url=http://www.hindu.com/mag/2006/11/26/stories/2006112600090300.htm|newspaper=[[The Hindu]]|date=26 November 2006|authorlink=Shashi Tharoor}} On his part Husain stated that leading Hindu leaders have not spoken a word against his paintings, and they should have been the first ones to have raised their voice and only people with political intentions created controversy.{{cite news|url=http://www.gulf-times.com/site/topics/article.asp?cu_no=2&item_no=365512&version=1&template_id=57&parent_id=56 |title=I just want to work in peace, says Husain |first=Nahla |last=Nainar |newspaper=[[Gulf Times]] |date=2 June 2010 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100607131252/http://www.gulf-times.com/site/topics/article.asp?cu_no=2&item_no=365512&version=1&template_id=57&parent_id=56 |archivedate=7 June 2010 }} After Husain's death, Shiv Sena chief [[Bal Thackeray]] said, "He only slipped up on the depiction of Hindu gods and goddesses. Otherwise, he was happy and content in his field. If his demise is a loss for modern art, then so be it. May Allah give him peace!"{{cite news|title=Husain only 'slipped up' on depiction of Hindu gods: Bal Thackeray|url=http://www.thehindu.com/news/national/article2091454.ece|newspaper=[[The Hindu]]|date=10 June 2011}}{{cite news|last=Mishra|first=Ambarish|title=Gave up the country, not his obduracy|url=http://articles.timesofindia.indiatimes.com/2011-06-10/india/29642114_1_m-f-husain-sena-leader-raj-thackeray|newspaper=[[The Times of India]]|date=10 June 2011|agency=[[Times News Network]]}}{{cite news|title=Bal Thackeray: MF Husain 'slipped'; Raj: Time to put controversies behind|url=http://www.dnaindia.com/india/report_bal-thackeray-m-f-husain-slipped-raj-time-to-put-controversies-behind_1552998|newspaper=[[Daily News and Analysis]]|date=9 June 2011|agency=[[Press Trust of India]]}} ==See also== * [[Bombay Progressive Artists' Group]] * [[Cubism]] * [[Expressionism]] * [[Bengal School of Art]] ==References== {{Reflist|colwidth=30em}} ==External links== {{Commons category}} {{external links|date=July 2017}} * [https://indiearts.in/product/m-f-husain-paintings-yeh-kaun-sa-modh/ M F Husain Paintings] * [http://www.mfhussain.com/ Husain's website] * [http://osianama.com/mast-art-0000389 M F Husain Artworks and Public Auction Prices 1987-2014] * [http://www.saffronart.com/artists/m-f-husain M F Husain profile and collection of artworks] * [http://www.archerindia.com/m-f-husain Limited Edition Prints and Serigraphs by M F Husain] * {{IMDb name|0403967}} * {{Worldcat id|lccn-n50-75752}} * [https://web.archive.org/web/20110707041914/http://timescontent.com/tss/showcase/virtual/photos/120/MF-Husain/1/d/MF-Husain.html%2C Collection of M.F. Husains's Good images] * [http://timesofindia.indiatimes.com/topic/MF-Husain MF Husain] collected news and commentary from ''[[The Times of India]]'' * [http://www.thehindu.com/news/national/article2091413.ece Requiem for M.F. Husain], N. Ram, ''[[The Hindu]]'', 10 June 2011 * {{NYTtopic|people/h/mf_husain}} * [http://www.ft.com/cms/s/2/edade830-9286-11e0-96e0-00144feab49a.html#axzz1Ooyk2F5Y Slideshow], ''[[Financial Times]]'' * [https://www.nytimes.com/2011/06/10/arts/design/maqbool-fida-husain-indias-most-famous-painter-dies-at-95.html?ref=design Maqbool Fida Husain, India’s ] * [http://art.prinseps.com/mf-husain-art-top/ MF Husain's Highest Auction Realisations By Year] {{Padma Vibhushan Awards}} {{PadmaBhushanAwardRecipients 1970–79}} {{Fellows of the Lalit Kala Akademi}} {{Authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Husain, M F}} [[Category:1915 births]] [[Category:2011 deaths]] [[Category:Gujarati people]] [[Category:Sulaymani Bohras]] [[Category:Indian Ismailis]] [[Category:Indian male painters]] [[Category:Naturalised citizens of Qatar]] [[Category:Artists from Indore]] [[Category:Indian emigrants to Qatar]] [[Category:Recipients of the Padma Bhushan in arts]] [[Category:Recipients of the Padma Vibhushan in arts]] [[Category:Sir J. J. School of Art alumni]] [[Category:Indian exiles]] [[Category:People from Solapur district]] [[Category:Indian portrait painters]] [[Category:Fellows of the Lalit Kala Akademi]] [[Category:20th-century Indian painters]] [[Category:Recipients of the Padma Shri in arts]] [[Category:Muslim artists]] [[Category:Burials at Brookwood Cemetery]] [[Category:Painters from Maharashtra]]

revision.text:
[[File:Ypsilanti Water Tower 2011.JPG|thumb|Ypsilanti Water Tower, winner of the Most Phallic Building contest]] The World's '''Most Phallic Building contest''' was a contest held in 2003 by ''[[Cabinet (magazine)|Cabinet]]'' magazine to find the building which most resembled a [[human penis|human phallus]].<ref>{{cite news |first=Lisa |last=Gutierrez |title=Another claim to fame for Liberty Memorial |url=http://nl.newsbank.com/nl-search/we/Archives?p_product=KC&p_theme=kc&p_action=search&p_maxdocs=200&p_topdoc=1&p_text_direct-0=0FFE6184248A5271&p_field_direct-0=document_id&p_perpage=10&p_sort=YMD_date:D&s_trackval=GooglePM |work=[[Kansas City Star]] |date=2003-12-29 |accessdate=2008-01-28 }}</ref>
==Background== The contest originated when writer [[Jonathan Ames]] drew the ire of ''[[Slate (magazine)|Slate]]'' readers by claiming, in a diary that was later published in his book ''I Love You More Than You Know'',<ref>{{cite news |first=Brendan |last=Halpin |title=Delightful essays of life's ups, downs in 'I Love You'; I Love You More Than You Know |url=https://pqasb.pqarchiver.com/latimes/access/990634401.html?dids=990634401:990634401&FMT=ABS&FMTS=ABS:FT&date=Feb+21%2C+2006&author=Brendan+Halpin&pub=Los+Angeles+Times&desc=BOOK+REVIEW%3B+Delightful+essays+of+life's+ups%2C+downs+in+%60I+Love+You'%3B+I+Love+You+More+Than+You+Know+Essays+Jonathan+Ames+Black+Cat%3A+270+pp.%2C+%2413+paper&pqatl=google |work=[[Los Angeles Times]] |date=2006-02-21 |accessdate=2008-01-28 }}</ref> that the [[Williamsburgh Savings Bank Tower|Williamsburg Bank Building]] in [[Brooklyn]], [[New York (state)|New York]] was the world's most phallic. This led ''Cabinet'' magazine to initiate a search of its own to find which building was truly the "world's most phallic".<ref>{{cite web | url = http://www.jonathanames.com/blog/archive/events/2003_07_13_archive.html| title = Most Phallic Building?| year=2007 | archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20111002073201/http://www.jonathanames.com/blog/archive/events/2003_07_13_archive.html|archive-date=2011-10-02|access-date=2016-11-10|dead-url=yes}}</ref><ref>{{cite web | url = http://gawker.com/news/realestate/the-most-phallic-building-in-the-world-contest-12901.php| title = Jonathan Ames article causes stir| year=2007|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090625120558/http://gawker.com/news/realestate/the-most-phallic-building-in-the-world-contest-12901.php|archive-date=2009-06-25|access-date=2016-11-10|dead-url=yes}}</ref><ref>{{cite web | url = http://www.forgotten-ny.com/STREET%20SCENES/willie/willie.html| title = Williamsburg Bank?| year=2007|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110808042704/http://www.forgotten-ny.com/STREET%20SCENES/willie/willie.html|archive-date=2011-08-08|access-date=2015-11-10|dead-url=yes}}</ref> Cities and readers subsequently poured in their views and staked their claims to the magazine's editors.
==Results== After months of entries and discussion, the [[Ypsilanti Water Tower]] in [[Ypsilanti]], [[Michigan]], was announced as the winner,<ref>{{cite news |title=A the awards: the 9 most remarkable things in culture this month.(man at his best) |url=http://www.accessmylibrary.com/coms2/summary_0286-19676527_ITM |work=[[Esquire (magazine)|Esquire]] |date=2004-01-01 |accessdate=2008-01-17 }}</ref> although the winner of a readers' poll was the [[Florida State Capitol]] building in [[Tallahassee]].<ref>{{cite news |first=Dan |last=Harrison |title=Site of the week |url=http://www.theage.com.au/articles/2003/11/05/1067989605047.html |work=[[The Age]] |date=2003-11-06 |accessdate=2008-01-28 }}</ref> Another notable nominee was the [[Torre Agbar]] (Agbar Tower) in [[Barcelona]].<ref>{{cite book |title=High Society: Contemporary Highrise Architecture and the International Highrise Award 2006 |last= Gräwe |first=Christina |author2=Schmal, Peter Cachola |year=2007 |publisher=Jovis |isbn=3-936314-77-2 |pages=Dust jacket |url=http://www.artbook.com/3936314772.html}}</ref>
''Cabinet'' noted that the Ypsilanti Water Tower, called "the brick dick" by locals, "is clearly the world's most phallic."<ref>{{cite web | url = http://www.cabinetmagazine.org/phallic/winner.php| title = Cabinet Magazine Winner |year=2007| archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20071002203209/http://www.cabinetmagazine.org/phallic/winner.php|archive-date=2007-10-02|access-date=2016-11-10|dead-url=yes }}</ref> The tower was designed by William R. Coats and constructed as part of an elaborate city waterworks project. Located on the highest point in [[Ypsilanti]], erection began in 1889 and was completed in 1890, at a cost of US$21,435.63.<ref name="YWT">"[http://www.michmarkers.com/startup.asp?startpage=L1591.htm Ypsilanti Water Tower] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120505024904/http://www.michmarkers.com/startup.asp?startpage=L1591.htm |date=2012-05-05 }}". Retrieved on 2009-01-16.</ref> Made of Joliet [[limestone]], the tower is 147 feet tall, has an 85-foot base and holds 250,000 gallons when full.<ref name="YWT"/>
==See also== * [[Phallic architecture]]
== References == {{Reflist}}

revision.text:
{{Essay-like|date=March 2011}} '''Music-on-demand''' is a music distribution model conceived with the growth of two-way computing, telecommunications and the [[Internet]] in the early 1990s. Primarily, high-quality music is made available to purchase, access and play back using software on the [[Apple Macintosh]], [[Microsoft Windows]], set-top boxes and mobile devices from an available distribution point, such as a computer host or server located at a telephone, cable TV or wireless data center facility.
In 1992, [[computer modem]] speeds were limited to less than 28 thousand bits per second (28 kbit/s), compared with uncompressed music on [[compact disc]] (CD) that required 150 thousand [[bytes]] per second. As a result, additional [[Bandwidth (computing)|bandwidth]] is required to accommodate delivering audio at CD quality standards: 16-bit frame, 44.1 [[kHz]] [[sampling rate]], stereophonic (two channel audio). This prompted telephony, [[CATV]], cellular and satellite providers to consider changing standards, assisting in creating the [[information superhighway]], in terms of building higher capacity for existing telecommunications [[infrastructure]]s.
Early attempts at designing and developing music-on-demand technology, in accordance with the laws of the United States such as the [[Audio Home Recording Act|Home Recording Act of 1992]], include [[Access Media Network]] (AMN) by inventor [[Dale Schalow]]. Schalow, born in Virginia, was an independent audio engineer and programmer in Los Angeles, California, who helped record albums and music scores for [[David Bowie]], [[Tin Machine]], [[Cypress Hill]], [[House of Pain]], [[Beastie Boys]], [[Interscope Records|Interscope]], and [[Warner Bros. Records|Warner Brothers]]. A [[multiplexed]] music-on-demand model was deployed using [[Pulse-code modulation|PCM]] audio sampling devices, Apple IIci, the [[Kermit (protocol)|KERMIT]] computer file transfer protocol, and [[SCSI]] storage systems by Schalow to validate processing 16-bit multi-channel audio from [[Point-to-point (telecommunications)|point-to-point]] in a professional recording studio environment, including his own independently operated '''Dascha''' company and '''38 Fresh Recordings'''. The model conceived was introduced by Schalow to Apple Computer in 1992 after he submitted an entry into the "I Changed the World" contest, essentially describing how an Apple computer helped shape and change the world forever based upon its usage. Apple acknowledged the "Accessible Music Network" (AMN) by awarding Schalow Honorable Mention and sending him a simple gray T-shirt with the Apple logo on it. Stand-alone software created by AMN for consumer-based access was then developed for the [[Microsoft Windows]] computer operating system, as well as set-top box design prototypes conceptualized with 3D prototype imaging that required a telephone connector located next to a [[coaxial]] cable TV connector to converge low speed data uplinking with high speed downloading interactive communications.
Presently, music-on-demand is still the center of controversy with a focus on illegal music downloading, [[peer-to-peer]] file swapping and the lag of legislation for rapidly changing technology on the Internet. Record labels represented by the [[RIAA]], as well as publishers and songwriters, have vigorously defended copyrighted materials and have been successful in enforcing current laws for protecting their intellectual property. As of 2006, the new music industry has seen a rapid growth in overall revenues for legal digital music sales that has resulted in hitting and surpassing one billion dollars annually.
== Bibliography ==
* TIME Magazine, 12 April 1993, Coming to Your TV Screen: The Info Highway * "I Changed the World" Apple Computer Contest, Spring, 1992, Cupertino, CA * {{cite journal|last1=Eisenmann|first1=Thomas R.|title=The U.S. Cable Television Industry, 1948-1995: Managerial Capitalism in Eclipse |journal=[[Business History Review]] |date=2000|volume=74|issue=1|pages=1–40}} * {{cite journal|last1=Stern|first1=Christopher|title=Bell Atlantic first with video dialtone|journal=[[Broadcasting & Cable]]|date=July 11, 1994|volume=124|issue=28|page=6|doi=10.2307/3116351}} * "AccessMusicNetwork.com Announces Internet Radio Toolkit for Professionals", 30 Nov 2007, PRNewswire via Reuters and James Madison University (Harrisonburg, Virginia), Alumni Newsroom (Public Relations) {{Use dmy dates|date=March 2011}}

revision.text:
'''New adult''' ('''NA''') '''fiction''', also rendered as '''new-adult fiction''', is a developing genre of fiction with protagonists in the 18–30 age bracket.<ref>Beckett, Sandra L. (2008). Crossover Fiction: Global and Historical Perspectives. pp. 111, 119–126.</ref> [[St. Martin's Press]] first coined the term in 2009, when they held a special call for "...fiction similar to YA that can be published and marketed as adult—a sort of an 'older YA' or 'new adult'".<ref name="GC1">{{cite web|title=St. Martin's New Adult Contest|url=http://sjaejones.com/blog/2009/st-martins-new-adult-contest|accessdate=19 May 2013}}</ref> New adult fiction tends to focus on issues such as leaving home, developing sexuality, and negotiating education and career choices.<ref>{{cite news|title=Would you read novels aimed at 'new adults'?|url=https://www.theguardian.com/books/2012/sep/10/new-adult-fiction|publisher=Guardian|accessdate=19 May 2013|location=London|first=Briony|last=Chappell|date=10 September 2012}}</ref> The genre has gained popularity rapidly over the last few years, particularly through books by self-published bestselling authors like Jennifer L. Armentrout, Cora Carmack, [[Colleen Hoover]], and Jamie McGuire.<ref>{{cite news|title=New Adult fiction is the hot new category in books|url=https://www.usatoday.com/story/life/books/2013/04/15/new-adult-genre-is-the-hottest-category-in-book-publishing/2022707/|publisher=USA Today|accessdate=19 May 2013|first1=Deirdre|last1=Donahue|date=15 April 2013}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=Karl Alexander Interview Part 3|url=http://www.fearnet.com/news/interview/karl-alexander-interview-part-3|publisher=FearNet|accessdate=19 May 2013}}</ref>
The genre was originally faced criticism, as some viewed it as a marketing scheme,<ref>{{cite web|title='New Adult' Fiction Is Now an Official Literary Genre Because Marketers Want Us to Buy Things|url=http://jezebel.com/5960942/new-adult-fiction-is-now-an-official-literary-genre-because-marketers-want-you-to-buy-things|publisher=Jezebel|accessdate=19 May 2013}}</ref> while others claimed the readership was not there to publish the material.<ref>{{cite web|title=New Adult: Needless Marketing-Speak Or Valued Subgenre?|url=http://www.publishersweekly.com/pw/by-topic/industry-news/publishing-and-marketing/article/55164-new-adult-needless-marketing-speak-or-valued-subgenre.html|publisher=Publishers Weekly|accessdate=19 May 2013}}</ref> In contrast, others claimed that the term was necessary; a publicist for [[HarperCollins]] described it as "a convenient label because it allows parents and bookstores and interested readers to know what is inside".<ref name="nytimes.com">{{cite news|title=Beyond Wizards and Vampires, to Sex|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2012/12/22/books/young-adult-authors-add-steaminess-to-their-tales.html?_r=1&|publisher=New York Times|accessdate=19 May 2013|first=Leslie|last=Kaufman|date=21 December 2012}}</ref>
Examples of books in the new adult genre include Sarah J. Maas' ''A Court of Thorns and Roses'' and ''Throne of Glass'', Jennifer L. Armentrout's ''Wait For You'', Jamie McGuire's ''Beautiful Disaster'',<ref>{{cite web|title='New Adult' books growing up|url=http://www.lansingstatejournal.com/article/20130420/THINGSTODO07/304200030/-New-Adult-books-growing-up|publisher=Lansing State Journal|accessdate=19 May 2013}}</ref> Colleen Hoover's ''Slammed'',<ref>{{cite web|title=Emerging 'New Adult' Book Genre Puts Smut Fiction on Bestseller Lists|url=http://abcnews.go.com/Entertainment/emerging-adult-book-genre-puts-smut-fiction-bestseller/story?id=18550587#.UZhSmKLFVqw|publisher=ABC News|accessdate=19 May 2013}}</ref> Cora Carmack's ''Losing It'',<ref>{{cite news|title=Are your teens ready for New Adult fiction?|url=http://www.suntimes.com/lifestyles/17501716-423/are-your-teens-ready-for-new-adult-fiction.html|publisher=Sun Times|accessdate=19 May 2013}}</ref> and [[Kendall Ryan (novelist)|Kendall Ryan]]'s ''The Impact of You''.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://happyeverafter.usatoday.com/2013/06/09/kendall-ryan-the-impact-of-you-new-adult/|title=Sexy-romance author Kendall Ryan gives New Adult a try|date=2013-06-09|website=Happy Ever After|access-date=2017-08-14}}</ref>
==Marketing== This category is intended to be marketed to [[Adolescence|post-adolescents]] and [[Young adult (psychology)|young-adults]] ages 18 to 30. This age group is considered to be the lucrative "cross-over" category of young-adult titles that appeal to both the young-adult market and to an adult audience.<ref>{{cite book|author=Beckett, Sandra L. |title=Crossover Fiction: Global and Historical Perspectives|pages= 111, 119–126|date= 2008}}</ref> Publishers of young-adult fiction now favor this category as it encompasses a far broader audience.<ref>{{Cite web |url=http://sjaejones.com/blog/2009/postadolescent-or-new-adult-fiction/ |title=Postadolescent or 'New Adult' Fiction |author= JJ |date=10 November 2009 |work= Publishing, Reviews |accessdate=15 September 2012}}</ref> The chief features that distinguish the new-adult fiction category from [[young adult fiction]] are the perspective of the young protagonist and the scope of the protagonist's life experience. Perspective is gained as childhood innocence fades and life experience is gained, which brings insight. It is this insight which is lacking in traditional young-adult fiction.<ref>{{Cite news |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2011/08/09/books/survey-shows-publishing-expanded-since-2008.html |title=Publishing Gives Hints of Revival, Data Show |first=Julie |last=Bosman |date= August 9, 2011 |accessdate=15 September 2012 |work=The New York Times}}</ref> The other main differences are characters' ages and the settings. YA does not usually include characters over age 18 or in college, but these characters are featured in new adult books. New adult can best be described as the age category after young adult.
==Themes and issues== New adult literature touches upon many themes and issues to reach the readership that falls in between the categories of young adult and adult fiction.
Many themes covered in young adult fiction such as identity, sexuality, depression, suicide, drug abuse, alcohol abuse, familial struggles, bullying<ref>[[young adult fiction]]</ref> are also covered in new adult fiction, but the various issues that are dealt with in the category hold it separate. Some common examples of issues include first jobs, starting college, wedding engagements and marriage, starting new families, friendships post-high school, military enlistment, financial independence, living away from home for the first time, empowerment, loss of innocence, and fear of failure.
This category focuses heavily on life after an individual has become of legal age, and how one deals with the new beginnings of adulthood. Commonly, these themes and issues have been seen taking place post-high school in popular new adult fiction titles, but there are exceptions.
==Genre== Like the fiction categories of young adult and adult, new adult fiction can combine with all genres and subgenres. [[Science fiction]], [[urban fiction]], [[Horror fiction|horror]], [[Paranormal fiction|paranormal]], [[dystopia]], etc. are some examples.
==Controversies==
===Publishing industry=== Many agents and large publishing houses have yet to recognize the category due to various issues.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.publishingcrawl.com/2013/01/30/new-adult-passing-trend-or-legitimate-genre/|title=New Adult- Passing Trend or Legitimate Genre?|date=30 January 2013|publisher=|accessdate=6 April 2018}}</ref> Some view the category as a marketing scheme, while others claim the readership is not there to publish the material.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.publishersweekly.com/pw/by-topic/industry-news/publishing-and-marketing/article/55164-new-adult-needless-marketing-speak-or-valued-subgenre.html|title=New Adult: Needless Marketing-Speak Or Valued Subgenre?|publisher=|accessdate=6 April 2018}}</ref> Therefore, authors have turned to self-publishing as a means to get their books out into the market.<ref name="usatoday.com">{{cite news| url=https://www.usatoday.com/story/life/books/2013/04/15/new-adult-genre-is-the-hottest-category-in-book-publishing/2022707/ | work=USA Today | first1=Deirdre | last1=Donahue | title=New Adult fiction is the hot new category in books | date=15 April 2013}}</ref> The success of these authors has led to many independent publishing houses and agents opening up to the category.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://paidcontent.org/2012/11/29/with-new-digital-imprints-random-house-taps-self-published-authors/|title=With new digital imprints, Random House taps self-published authors|first=Laura|last=Owen|date=29 November 2012|website=paidcontent.org|accessdate=6 April 2018}}</ref> Publishers are now publishing these books with many of the bestsellers having deals with large publishers.<ref name="usatoday.com"/>
===Sex=== In 2012, new adult fiction saw a rise in the romance subgenre of contemporary when self-published titles such as ''Slammed'' by [[Colleen Hoover]], ''Easy'' by Tamarra Webber, and ''[[Beautiful Disaster (novel)|Beautiful Disaster]]'' by [[Jamie McGuire (author)|Jamie McGuire]] got picked up by major publishing houses. Some believe<ref name=autogenerated1>{{cite news| url=https://www.nytimes.com/2012/12/22/books/young-adult-authors-add-steaminess-to-their-tales.html?_r=0 | work=The New York Times | first=Leslie | last=Kaufman | title=Young-Adult Authors Are Creating a Steamy New Genre | date=21 December 2012}}</ref> this jump in response to the category came from the release of the popular erotic novel ''[[Fifty Shades of Grey]]'', which featured a heroine in college.<ref name="nytimes.com"/> Since new adult fiction tackles issues such as sex and sexuality and many of the categories' successful titles deal with those same issues the category itself and the single issue of sex have been stated as synonymous,<ref name="nytimes.com"/> and even been called over-sexualized versions of young adult fiction.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://abcnews.go.com/Entertainment/emerging-adult-book-genre-puts-smut-fiction-bestseller/story?id=18550587|title=Emerging 'New Adult' Book Genre Puts Smut on Top|first=A. B. C.|last=News|date=23 February 2013|website=ABC News|accessdate=6 April 2018}}</ref> Both readers and authors of the category combat the claim by stating that the category deals with the exploration of a character's life,<ref>{{cite web|url=http://dearauthor.com/features/letters-of-opinion/new-adult-its-not-about-the-sex-but-dont-be-afraid-of-the-sex-either/|title=New Adult: It’s not about the sex (but don’t be afraid of the sex either)|date=25 December 2012|publisher=|accessdate=6 April 2018}}</ref> and that sex is not ubiquitous in new adult titles.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.ebscohost.com/novelist/novelist-special/what-is-new-adult-fiction-anyway|title=What is New Adult Fiction, Anyway? - NoveList - EBSCOhost|website=www.ebscohost.com|accessdate=6 April 2018}}</ref>
==2009 to present== Following the end of the St. Martin's Press contest, the new adult category has become increasingly popular through self-publishing. Major New York publishers are taking self-published authors of these titles and acquiring them for mass market sales. Some authors include:
*Cora Carmack for ''Losing It''<ref>{{cite news|url=http://mediadecoder.blogs.nytimes.com/2012/11/14/self-published-author-signs-a-three-book-deal-heralding-new-adult-fiction/|title=Self-Published Author Signs a Three-Book Deal, Heralding New Adult Fiction|date=14 November 2012|accessdate=14 November 2012|work=The New York Times|first=Leslie|last=Kaufman}}</ref> *Kathy Clark released a new-adult genre novel in her ''Scandals'' series titled ''Due Dates'' in November, 2013<ref>{{cite web|title=Due Dates (Scandals Book 1) at Amazon|work=Amazon.com|url=https://www.amazon.com/DUE-DATES-SCANDALS-Kathy-Clark-ebook/dp/B00GQC1S3O}}</ref> *Sylvia Day for ''Reflected in You''<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.publishersweekly.com/pw/by-topic/industry-news/publishing-and-marketing/article/55164-new-adult-needless-marketing-speak-or-valued-subgenre.html|title=New Adult: Needless Marketing-Speak Or Valued Subgenre?|date=14 December 2012|accessdate=14 December 2012}}</ref> * [[Colleen Hoover]] for ''Slammed'' and ''Point of Retreat''<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.prnewswire.com/news-releases/atria-books-inks-deal-with-new-york-times-bestselling-self-published-author-colleen-hoover-165744026.html |title=Atria Books Inks Deal With New York Times Bestselling Self-Published Author Colleen Hoover |date=10 August 2012 |accessdate=16 September 2012}}</ref> * Jamie McGuire for ''Beautiful Disaster''<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.publishersweekly.com/pw/by-topic/industry-news/industry-deals/article/52953-atria-inks-self-pub-d-bestseller-mcguire-to-two-book-deal.html |title=Atria Inks Self-Pub'd Bestseller McGuire to Two-Book Deal |first=Rachel |last=Deahl |date= 11 July 2012 |accessdate=15 September 2012}}</ref> * Tammara Webber for ''Easy''<ref>{{cite web|url=http://tammarawebber.blogspot.com/2012/09/penguinrazorbill-uk-announcement.html |title=Penguin/Razorbill UK Announcement |accessdate=15 September 2012}}</ref>
==Authors== Some noteworthy authors of the category include: {{div col|colwidth=30em}} * [[Jennifer Armentrout|Jennifer L. Armentrout / J. Lynn]] * [[Gemma Burgess]] * [[Katy Evans]] * [[Abbi Glines]] * [[Colleen Hoover]] * [[J.A. Redmerski]] * [[Sylvain Reynard]] * [[Jessica Sorensen]] * [[Tammara Webber]] * [[Sarah J Maas]] * [[Lev Grossman]] * [[Ernest Cline]] * [[Patrick Rothfuss]] * [[Kendall Ryan (novelist)|Kendall Ryan]]{{div col end}}
==References== {{Reflist|3}}
== External links == *[https://www.goodreads.com/shelf/show/new-adult-fiction Goodreads.com: List of popular New-adult fiction books]

{{Infobox film | name = Orgasmic Birth: The Best-Kept Secret | director = Debra Pascali-Bonaro | producer = Debra Pascali-Bonaro
Kris Liem | music = John McDowell
Sabina Sciubba | editing = Kris Liem | released = '''United States:''' January 2, 2009 (first primetime showing) | runtime = 85 minutes | language = [[English language|English]], [[Portuguese language|Portuguese]], [[French language|French]], [[German language|German]], [[Spanish language|Spanish]] }} '''''Orgasmic Birth: The Best-Kept Secret''''' (also called '''''Orgasmic Birth: 11 Mothers, 12 International Experts''''' or just '''''Orgasmic Birth''''') is a 2008 [[documentary film]] that examines the intimate nature of birth.[http://www.orgasmicbirth.com/what-is-orgasmic-birth Orgasmicbirth.com, What is Orgasmic Birth] It had been shown at women's and film festivals since May 2008, before being shown for the first time in [[primetime]] on January 2, 2009 by ABC’s [[20/20 (U.S. TV series)|20/20]].{{cite web|last=Belkin |first=Lisa |url=http://parenting.blogs.nytimes.com/2008/12/11/orgasms-during-childbirth/ |title=Orgasms During Childbirth? - NYTimes.com |publisher=Parenting.blogs.nytimes.com |date=2008-12-11 |accessdate=2012-07-19}} The documentary follows the journey of eleven women through labour, presenting how blissful birth can be.{{cite news | url= http://www.highbeam.com/doc/1P3-1668525751.html | title= Orgasmic Birth: The Best Kept Secret | publisher=''Contemporary Sexuality'' | author= Linda Newhart Lotz | date= March 1, 2009 | accessdate=November 13, 2009}}{{cite news | url= http://www.theage.com.au/opinion/orgasmic-birth-and-other-old-midwives-tales-20081229-76sd.html | title= Orgasmic birth and other old midwives' tales | publisher=''[[The Age]]'' | author= Avril Moore | date=December 30, 2008 | accessdate=November 13, 2009}}{{cite news | url= http://abcnews.go.com/Health/story?id=6120045&page=1 | title= Labor Orgasms Called 'Best-Kept Secret' | publisher=''[[ABC News]]'' | author= [[Juju Chang]] and Gail Deutsch | date=December 9, 2008 | accessdate=November 13, 2009}} Interviews with experts, ([[doula]]s, doctors, [[Midwifery|midwives]], [[Gynaecology|gynecologists]], [[anthropology|anthropologists]], [[Neonatology|neonatologists]], nurses, [[Lamaze technique|Lamaze]] educators, and mothers and fathers) explore how the birthing process has become a medical procedure rather than a natural process.{{cite news | url= http://www.greenmuze.com/reviews/films/856-orgasmic-birth-.html | title= Orgasmic Birth | publisher=''Greenmuze.com'' | author= | date=February 24, 2009 | accessdate=November 13, 2009}} Noted narrators include [[Ina May Gaskin]]. While the documentary features several mothers who claim to have had an [[birthgasm|orgasm during labor]], it is primarily about natural labour at the home without drugs.{{cite news | url= http://www.irishtimes.com/newspaper/health/2009/0324/1224243299509.html | title= The orgasmic way to avoid hard labour | publisher=''[[The Irish Times]]'' | author= Viv Groskop | date= March 24, 2009 | accessdate=November 13, 2009}}{{cite news | url= http://www.msnbc.msn.com/id/23239361/ | title= Pioneering midwife touts 'orgasmic birth' | publisher=''[[MSNBC]] (AP)'' | author= | date= February 24, 2008 | accessdate=November 13, 2009}} ==Book== ''Orgasmic Birth: Your Guide to a Safe, Satisfying, and Pleasurable Birth Experience'' by Elizabeth Davis and Debra Pascali-Bonaro, was first published on June 8, 2010. ==DVD release== The [[DVD]] was released in the United States on January 1, 2009, and soon after an international version was released.[http://orgasmicbirth.com OrgasmicBirth.com] ==Soundtrack== The [[soundtrack]] was created by John McDowell (composer of the score for the documentary ''[[Born Into Brothels]]''), with additional composition by Sabina Sciubba (of the group [[Brazilian Girls]]). It is available to buy on [[CD]]. ==See also== *''[[The Business of Being Born]]'' *[[Homebirth]] *[[Waterbirth]] ==References== ==External links== *[http://www.orgasmicbirth.com/ Official Website] *{{IMDb title|1331111|Orgasmic Birth: The Best-Kept Secret}} [[Category:Books and art about childbirth]] [[Category:Orgasm]] [[Category:American documentary films]] [[Category:American films]] [[Category:2000s documentary films]] [[Category:Pregnancy films]]

{| class="infobox bordered" style="width: 25em; text-align: left; font-size: 95%;" |+ style="font-size: larger;" | '''Oxford University Society of Bibliophiles''' |- | colspan="2" style="text-align:center;" | [[File:OUSB Device.jpg|245px|center]] |- ! Founded | 1950 (restored 2008) |- | colspan="2" style="text-align:center;" | '''Society officers, [[Hilary Term]] 2016''' |-
|- ! Honorary President | [[Henry Woudhuysen]], [[Rector (academia)|Rector]], [[Oxford|Lincoln College]] |- ! Honorary Vice-President | Paul W Nash, [[Bodleian Library]] |- ! President | Daniel Fried, [[New College, Oxford|New College]] |- ! Vice-President | Elle Pfeffer, [[Worcester College, Oxford|Worcester]] |- ! Secretary | Simon Korneev, [[St Catherine's College, Oxford|St Catherine's]] |- ! Treasurer | Constanta Burlacu, [[Merton College, Oxford|Merton]] |- ! Senior Committee | Geri Della Rocca de Candal, Cristina Dondi, [[Colin Franklin (bibliographer)|Colin Franklin]], Giles Mandelbrote, Scott Mandelbrote, [[Richard Ovenden]], William Poole, Julia Walworth. |- | colspan="2" style="font-size: smaller;" | |}
The '''Oxford University Society of Bibliophiles''' is a [[book collecting]] and [[Bibliophilia|bibliophile]] club run by, and primarily for, students at [[Oxford University]]. It was founded in 1950 by a group of young bibliophiles headed by John Granger, Bent Juel-Jensen and R. John Rickett, and the first meeting was held in Hilary Term of 1951.<ref>Nash and Howes 2006, p. 11.</ref> For fifty years the Society held regular lectures, visits and other events during the University terms, and many of the leading [[Bibliography|bibliographers]], [[librarians]], book collectors, [[booksellers]] and other literary figures of the period spoke to the Society or hosted visits. Many of the Society's junior members went on to become prominent figures in the world of books, and some later served as senior members of the Society. One of the most influential members was [[John Hanbury Angus Sparrow|John Sparrow]], Warden of All Souls, who encouraged a love of books and manuscripts in a generation of students, and hosted a termly "Warden's Meeting"<ref>Davies et al. 1977.</ref> at which members were encouraged to bring items from their own libraries to pass round and say a few words about; the tradition of the "Warden's Meeting" continued after 1986, when the Warden himself was too ill to host the meetings and, indeed, after his death in 1992. Another of the Society's traditions was the quality of the termly programme cards, often produced by the leading printers and [[private presses]] of the age, including the [[Oxford University Press|Oxford]] and [[Cambridge University Press|Cambridge]] University Presses, the [[Rampant Lions Press]], the [[Samson Press]], the [[Fantasy Press (UK)|Fantasy Press]], the [[Kit-Cat Press]], [[Big Wheel Press]], the [[Perpetua Press]], the [[Incline Press]], the [[Whittington Press]], the [[Libanus Press]], the [[Rocket Press]], the [[Stanbrook Abbey]] Press and the [[Officina Bodoni|Stamperia Valdonega]].<ref>Nash and Howes 2006, plates 1-4 and pp. 25-180.</ref>
After a period of difficulties and disrupted activities in the last decade of the twentieth century, the Society closed in 2000, when interest among the students had declined so far that a junior committee could no longer be formed. However, due to the efforts of a new generation of Oxford students led by Geri Della Rocca de Candal, Enrico Emanuele Prodi and Matthew Cheung Salisbury, aided by Cristina Dondi, [[Richard Ovenden]] and a few surviving members of the former Society (notably [[Colin Franklin (writer and bibliographer)|Colin Franklin]] and Paul W. Nash), the Oxford University Society of Bibliophiles was refounded in [[Trinity term]] 2008 and became fully active in [[Michaelmas term]] in the same year. The first termcard for the new Society was printed by the Rampant Lions Press (and was among the last jobs printed by Sebastian Carter).
The Society's device, shown opposite, was designed by [[Michael Harvey (lettering artist)|Michael Harvey]].
==Presidents of the revived Society [2008-present]==
- * Trinity Term 2008 to Trinity Term 2009 - Geri Della Rocca de Candal, University College - * Michaelmas Term 2009 - William Kelley, St. John's College * Hilary Term 2010 - Richard Foster, Corpus Christi College * Trinity Term 2010 - Enrico Emanuele Prodi, Merton College - * Michaelmas Term 2010 - Mark Scott, Mansfield College * Hilary Term 2011 - Marco Paoletti, St. John's College * Trinity Term 2011 - Lucy Fisher, University College - * Michaelmas Term 2011 - Kelsey Jackson Williams, Balliol College * Hilary Term 2012 - Jan Willem Scholten, Corpus Christi College * Trinity Term 2012 - Juliet Wesley, Somerville College - * Michaelmas Term 2012 - Harriet Rix, St. Edmund's College * Hilary Term 2013 - Lara Verena Bellenghi, St. Hugh's College * Trinity Term 2013 - Henry Mason, Merton College - * Michaelmas Term 2013 - Emma Rix, Corpus Christi College * Hilary Term 2014 - Tom Cummings, Corpus Christi College * Trinity Term 2014 - Melinda Letts, Christ Church - * Michaelmas Term 2014 - Michael Malone-Lee, University College * Hilary Term 2015 - Theophilius Kwek, Merton College * Trinity Term 2015 - Karen Caines, Trinity College - * Michaelmas Term 2015 - Paul Ostwald, Regent's Park * Hilary Term 2016 - John Ryan, Lincoln College * Trinity Term 2016 - Matilde Malaspina, Lincoln College - * Michaelmas Term 2016 - Elle Pfeffer, Worcester College * Hilary Term 2017 - Marcos Barclay, Regent's Park College * Trinity Term 2017 - Matilde Malaspina, Lincoln College - * Michaelmas Term 2017 - Gustave Laurent, St Antony’s College & Mariachiara Leteo, Lincoln College * Hilary Term 2018 - Elle Pfeffer, Worcester College * Trinity Term 2018 - Angeline Rais, Lincoln College
-
*Michaelmas Term 2018 - Daniel Fried, New College

{{one source|date=October 2014}} {{Infobox artist | name = Pál Böhm | image = Böhm Pál.jpg | image_size = | alt = | caption = Pál Böhm | native_name = | native_name_lang = | birth_name = | birth_date = 28 December 1839 | birth_place = Nagyvárad, Hungary | death_date = 29 March 1905 | death_place = Munich, Germany | resting_place = | nationality = Hungarian | residence = | education = | alma_mater = | known_for = Painter | notable_works = | style = | movement = [[Orientalism|Orientalist]] | spouse = | partner = | awards = | elected = | patrons = | memorials = | website = | module = }} '''Pál (Paul) Böhm''' (28 December 1839, [[Nagyvárad]] - 29 March 1905, [[Munich]]) was a Hungarian [[Genre art|genre]] painter. ==Life and work== He first studied drawing with his father, who was a maintenance engineer at the bishop's manor. After finishing elementary school, he tried his hand at many crafts, including carpentry, [[coppersmith]]ing and toy making. In 1859, he joined a group of scenery painters and learned that craft from {{ill|Antal Haan|hu|Haan Antal}}.[http://mek.oszk.hu/00300/00355/html/ABC00523/02237.htm Böhm Pál] @ Magyar Elektronikus Könyvtár In 1862, he finally decided to become a painter, eventually travelling to Vienna, where he copied the works on display in the [[Belvedere, Vienna|Belvedere Palace]]. In 1865, he returned to his hometown and attempted to make a living by painting portraits and altarpieces. He also briefly operated a painting school that was attended by [[László Paál]]. Two years later, he was sufficiently established to earn a decent living and moved to Budapest, where he exhibited with the National Society of Hungarian Fine Arts. In 1871, he received a scholarship from [[Tivadar Pauler]], the Minister of Religion and Education. This enabled him to travel to Munich, where he quickly became part of the city's artistic life and associated with a group of Hungarian painters led by [[Géza Mészöly (painter)|Géza Mészöly]]. On several occasions, he stayed in the [[Tisza]] region, where he painted and sketched, but settled in Munich permanently in 1875. After this point, his paintings lost some of their freshness and are generally considered by critics to be rather commercial. ==Selected paintings== File:Böhm Betlehemes készülődés 1870.jpg|Preparing for the Nativity (1870) File:Pál Böhm Scene at the Bank of River 1873-75.jpg|Scene on the Banks of the Tisza River (1873) File:Böhm, Pál - Tumbril.jpg|The [[Tumbrel]]
(date unknown) File:Pal Böhm Im Münchner Hofbräuhaus.jpg|At a Brewery in Munich
(date unknown) ==References== {{reflist}} == Further reading == * György Seregélyi: ''Magyar festők és grafikusok adattára'' (Database of Hungarian Painters and Graphic Artists), Szeged, 1988, {{ISBN|963-500-817-1}} * ''Művészeti lexikon'' (Art Lexicon) (edited by Nóra Aradi), Akadémiai Kiadó, 1983, {{ISBN|963-05-2360-4}} * Károly Lyka: ''Nemzeti romantika'' (National Romanticism), Corvina Kiadó, Budapest, 1982, {{ISBN|963-13-1228-3}} == External links == {{commons category|Pál Böhm}} * [http://www.mke.hu/lyka/04/181-186-bohm.htm Művészet] An appreciation and brief biography of Böhm by [[Viktor Olgyai]]. * [http://www.artnet.com/artists/p%C3%A1l-paul-b%C3%B6hm/past-auction-results ArtNet: More works by Böhm] {{authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Bohm, Pal}} [[Category:Genre painters]] [[Category:Orientalism]] [[Category:Orientalist painters]] [[Category:People from Oradea]] [[Category:1839 births]] [[Category:1905 deaths]] [[Category:19th-century Hungarian painters]]
